"The plan of restricting traffic on one block of certain streets in the congested sections of the city first tried in the summer of 1914 resulted in the use of 25 streets during the summer of 1915. These streets were closed usually from 3 to 6 each afternoon although some were closed during the whole day while others were closed from 7 00 to 9 00. in the evening the hours of closing depending upon the demands of the neighborhood. Stanchions were placed at each end of the block and a police officer was stationed there to direct traffic. During the summer there was a total attendance of 92,331 children on these play streets. Play streets at best are a makeshift but there have been two beneficial results. a A more intimate relationship between the children and the policeman. b A decrease in the number of street accidents to children in the vicinity of these play streets." March, 1916 "The Delinquent" , monthly publication by the Prison Association of New York. books.google.com/books?id=k0rNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA177#v=one..., The Play Streets concept persists in New York. Tamara Platonovna Karsavina (10 March 1885 – 26 May 1978) was a famous Russian ballerina, renowned for her beauty, who was most noted as a Principal Artist of the Imperial Russian Ballet and later the Ballets Russes of Serge Diaghilev. After settling in Hampstead, England, she began teaching ballet professionally and would become recognised as one of the founders of modern British ballet. She assisted in the establishment of The Royal Ballet and was a founder member of the Royal Academy of Dance, which is now the world's largest dance teaching organisation. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamara_Karsavina

NYT of July 13, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70F1FFA3F5E13738... describes a garden created for the blind on the roof of the new United States Bank Building on Delancey St.

Oddly, there is another NYT article from the week before which seems to be describing the same event, only at the Bank of the United States Building at 77 Delancey Street. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D05E3DF1038E633A... The story of the Bank and its founder Joseph S. Marcus "a Jewish immigrant to the United States. Born in the town of Telz in Germany in 1862, he went to school in Essen and immigrated to the United States at the age of 17 and worked his way up from being a tailor, to a garment industry business, to a banker. He founded the Public Bank in 1906 and the Bank of United States in 1913" is an interesting one. It was Marcus who created and donated this rooftop garden. The Bank was the first to collapse at the onset of the Great Depression. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_United_States The Bank's first building at 77 Delancey Street, from 1914, has obviously seen better days:

To the far right of what can be seen of the viaduct is the wider steel sheathing under the roadway that marks the 125th Street arch, the especially wide arch needed to span that intersection at 12th Avenue. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverside_Drive_Viaduct September 2011 Google Street View from the Henry Hudson Parkway maps.google.com/maps?q=brook+avenue,+nyc+map&hl=en&am... Finally found some news accounts. This was not a Morse airplane, but an airplane carrying a Morse, Erwin A. Morse, son of Charles W. Morse, New York financier and shipbuilder. Edwin Morse intended to start air service between Albany and New York at the 132d Street Pier. On the first day of service, July 11, 1915, he and his pilot hit a log or railroad tie floating in the North/Hudson River, and the plane flipped over. Neither was seriously hurt. The New York Tribune ran a flippant account, accompanied by a picture of the wreckage being towed to the dock by a rowboat. The "flying boat" was made by The Wright Co. in Dayton, Ohio, for the Hudson=Wright Aero Company. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-07-12/ed-... The company had also announced in June that their flying school was opening at the 132d street pier. books.google.com/books?id=st1LAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA566&... Here is the account from the New York Evening Telegram: "AEROPLANE UPSETS IN RIVER: TWO RESCUED -••- Erwin A. Morse and A. B. Gaines Have Narrow Escapes When Machine Strikes Log and Turns Turtle on First Albany to New York Passenger Trip. In the sight of thousands of persons along the North River to-day, a hydro-aeroplane In which were A. B. Gaines and Erwin A. Morse," son of Charles W. Morse, was disabled and turned turtle In the middle of the stream. Both men were rescued by boats which put out quickly from the shore, and the machine, which did not sink, was towed in to a pier. The accident marred what was intended to be the inauguration of a regular hydroaeroplane passenger service between this city and Albany. Mr. Morse, who is manager of the Hudson Navigation Company, is interested in the new project and went in the aero-plane as a passenger. The machine was piloted by Mr. Gaines. They intended to fly to Albany and left the hangar at the foot of West 132d street at eight o'clock. Mr. Gaines had previously made a short flight to test the machine and had found everything all right. When he left the water for the long flight the pilot sent the machine up about thirty feet, then started off at a sixty mile an hour speed. After going a short distance at this height, Mr. Gaines decided to come down within five or six feet of the water. In makingthe dip the bow of the hydroaeroplane struck a log. The keel of the machine was split and a wing broken and it immediately turned over in the water. Mr. Morse was thrown into the river and started to swim for shore, but Mr.Gaines clung to the wreckage. The machine was then about in the middle of tne river. Crowds that had gathered to watch the flight saw the accident and there was great excitement. Dozens of launches and rowboats from the yacht clubs along the shore put out to the rescue. A launch from a private yacht that was anchored well out in the stream was the first to reach the men and take them aboard. The victims of the mishap were landed at West 132d street and the machine was towed to a point a short distance away. Just at this time the steamboat Rensselaer, of the Hudson Navigation Company,came along on its trip from Albany and the two men got aboard and went down to pier No. 32, where Mr. Morse has living quarters. After a change of clothing the two men had breakfast. Mr. Morse took his experience as a minor mishap and said he would start again as soon as the machine was repaired." fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin...

Marble House is one of the Gilded Age mansions of Newport, Rhode Island, now open to the public as a museum run by the Newport Preservation Society. It was designed by the architect Richard Morris Hunt, and said to be inspired by the Petit Trianon at Versailles (which it resembles in little more than pilasters and balustrades). Its temple-front portico, which also serves as a porte-cochère, has been compared to that of the White House. Grounds were designed by noted landscape architect Ernest W. Bowditch. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marble_House

SS St. Louis, was a transatlantic passenger liner built by the William Cramp & Sons Building & Engine Company, Philadelphia and was launched on 12 November 1894; sponsored by Mrs. Grover Cleveland, wife of the President of the United States; and entered merchant service in 1895, under United States registry for the International Navigation Co., of New York with her maiden voyage between New York and Southampton, England. She was acquired by the United States Navy during the Spanish–American War and commissioned under the name USS St. Louis in 1898, and again during World War I under the name USS Louisville (ID-1644) from 1918 to 1919.[Note 1] After she reverted to her original name in 1919, she burned in 1920 while undergoing a refit. St. Louis was scrapped in 1924 in Genoa. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_St._Louis_(1894)

In July, 1915, Thaw had a jury trial solely on the issue of his present sanity, bearing on whether he would be returned to the Matteawan State Hospital from which he had escaped 2 years earlier. The trial was in the Tweed Courthouse, still standing on Chambers Street. This picture is more likely to be Thaw heading to court, rather than leaving, as it looks like he is on Centre and Chambers, walking toward the courthouse. That would put it in front of the Manhattan Municipal Building, which has an arched pathway through its center. www.nyc.gov/html/dcas/html/resources/man_munibldg.shtml The spot in July, 2011 via Google Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=51+chambers+street,+nyc&ll=40.... See notes under: Reflecting further, I suppose he could be on the presumably identical inside of the passageway, therefore heading away from court.
Lovely Visit www.flickr.com/photos/rose_gallery/
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Kendall_Thaw

Actually, not the courthouse, but instead the photo was taken in front of the Ludlow Street Jail, no longer standing. The sign by the front door reads "New York County Jail" (New York County is essentially Manhattan), and that is what the Ludlow Street Jail was. Thaw, in 1915, was returned to New York City after escaping confinement at Matteawan State Hospital (He had been acquitted of the 1906 murder of architect Stanford White by reason of insanity). His lawyers successfully asked the court to move him from The Tombs to the Ludlow Street Jail, on the basis that he was not charged in a criminal matter, but that he was to have a jury trial only as to his present sanity. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10916F93E5D16738... In this old print, you can see that the door was near the corner of Ludlow and Essex Market Place. [Essex Market Place ran from Essex to Ludlow Streets between Broome and Grand Streets and was closed in 1926, around the time the jail was demolished.] You can see that there was a giant gas lamp over the door, whereas in Bain's 1915 picture just the bracket remained. digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm... knickerbockervillage.blogspot.com/2009/10/seward-park-aer... This was probably taken when Thaw was due to be taken from the jail to court. He and 5 others who helped him escape the state hospital were tried in March, 1915 and acquitted. He then had a second trial in 1915 to determine if he was presently sane. He was determined sane in this trial on July 14, 1915, which is presumably about when this shot was taken. The New York Times account describes 2,000 people gathered at the courthouse, cheering thaw after the trial: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E10FC3E5A15738... See also:

And not to forget, the Thaw trials were about Evelyn Nesbit Thaw, or more exactly Thaw's shooting of her presumed lover, Stanford White.

This is taken from an upper story window near 62 Essex Street, at the corner of Essex Market Place, a street which was closed in 1926 which ran between Essex and Ludlow, on the block between Grand and Broome. Coincidentally, the photo 2 in front of this one in the news stream was taken at the other end of Essex Market Place, at the Ludlow corner, in front of the Ludlow Street Jail. The buildings on both sides of this block have been demolished since this photo was taken. The building on the northeast corner of Essex and Broome, just visible in back of the wagon at the very top under the word July, is still there. The details of the spirited conversations, pushcart vendors and street life on the Lower East Side in general are well captured. It's not unlikely that the same photographer took both photos on the same day. This picture is wonderful in the highest resolution at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.19510 . The view from the approximate location, at street level, in July, 2011: maps.google.com/maps?q=62+essex+street,+nyc&ll=40.716...

In 1854, the U.S. Sloop of War CONSTELLATION was launched from Gosport. With similar dimensions to her famous predecessor, she carried 22 guns, had a crew compliment of 240 men, and displaced 1,400 tons with a beam of 42 feet and length of 176 feet. The new ship's first assignment was interdicting the slave trade off the coast of Africa. She captured two slavers and released the imprisoned slaves. At the outbreak of the Civil War, CONSTELLATION made the first Union Navy capture, overpowering the slaver brig TRITON in coastal waters off Africa. After the war, CONSTELLATION saw various duties such as carrying famine relief stores to Ireland and carrying precious American works of art to the Paris Exposition of 1895. In 1894, CONSTELLATION became a training ship for the Naval Training Center in Newport, R.I. In addition to being used extensively as a training ship for Naval Academy midshipmen, she also helped train more than 60,000 recruits during World War I. Decommissioned in 1933, CONSTELLATION was re-commissioned as a national symbol on August 24, 1940 by President Franklin Roosevelt. Shortly after the country's entry into World War II, she became the flagship for Admiral Ernest J. King and Admiral Royal Ingersoll. The treasured warship was decommissioned in February 1955 and was taken "home" to her permanent berth in Baltimore Harbor. Now a National Historic Landmark, she is the last existing Civil War era naval vessel and the last sail-powered warship built by the U.S. Navy. www.ussconstellation.org/constellation_history.html

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Constellation_%281854%29 Currently moored in Baltimore's Inner Harbor. "In 1994 Constellation was condemned as an unsafe vessel. She was towed to a drydock at Fort McHenry in 1996, and her $9 million restoration project was completed in July 1999. On 26 October 2004, Constellation made her first trip out of Baltimore's Inner Harbor since 1955. The trip to the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis lasted six days, and it marked her first trip to Annapolis in 111 years."

From www.cnic.navy.mil/Newport/About/History/index.htm "World War I brought a tremendous increase in naval activity to Newport as thousands of young men arrived for training. Coaster's Harbor Island was unable to accommodate this influx, and land at Coddington Point was added to the Navy's holdings. Almost overnight, the Point was turned into a city of tents and wooden buildings as more than 75,000 recruits passed through Newport. Residents of the city were encouraged to "Adopt a Sailor," opening their homes as temporary lodging for the trainees. As the Navy expanded, what had been the Second Naval District (the Naval Training Station) was combined with the First Naval District in 1919."

As much as I love photography, I also hate it because we'll never get images like this again.  People now are exposed to images of others and have become completely self-conscious and self-aware because of it.  Most of these boys had probably only seen a handful of photos at this point.  There's still such an easiness in front of the camera - they don't know that they "should" look a certain way.  They just look the way they look and people accept them for it.  There are a few looking at the camera, but I think it's more out of curiosity than anything else - maybe a feeling of "I can't believe someone's making a picture of me."

See archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/BREESE/2000-01/094... 'Frances Tileston Breese, my Grandmother, was born on November 29, 1893 in New York City and died near her father's mansion "The Orchard" in on June 13, 1985 in Southampton, L.I., NY. She wrote three wonderful autobiographies: "Tanty," "More About Tanty," and "Tanty: The Daring Decades." She was a fascinating person and a wonderful artist. She studied art in Paris, and after raising her children divorced my Grandfather to pursue her art: modern design and primitive painting. This took her to Haiti where she met and married a black Haitian and tried to bring him back into New York Society in the 50's! She designed and built one of the first modern beach houses on Long Island, "The Sandbox."'

There's a mention of "Miss Jean Potter and Miss Charlotte Potter" being "on the beach" at Southampton in summer 1922 (apparently visiting for the festivities surrounding a tennis tournament): chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1922-07-07/ed-... "Jean and Charlotte Potter" took part in a 1922 circus-themed fair at Agawam Park, to benefit Southampton Hospital (they helped run the roasted peanuts and popcorn concession). query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00D16FF385D1A7A9... The two Potter girls are also listed among the young women selling programs for a performance at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton that year (New York Tribune, 3 September 1922). I think they're the daughters of banker William Chapman Potter and Caroline Morton Potter, who were divorcing in 1922 (which might account for the girls' busy social calendar that year). Reports about the divorce mention they have two daughters, 17 and 19. Mrs. Potter was residing in Paris at the time. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A15FB355A1B7A9... They had a half-sister, Diana Guggenheim (1924-1991), aka Diane Hamilton: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diane_Hamilton Jean Potter married artist Frederick Soldwedel; they divorced in 1930. Then she married Lt. Edmund C. Stout; she was widowed in 1943 when he died from an accidental gunshot wound in their home in Florida. Charlotte Potter married Reginald M. Lewis in 1926, and divorced him in 1930; then she married a man named Atwood, as his second wife, c1932.

Ange-Francois Cyprien Troussaint, M.D. Director-General of the French Army Medical Service. The hospital he was inspecting, the gift of New Yorkers Gibson, Clarence and William Fahnestock, is described in the Journal of the American Medical Association, June 26, 1915: " AN AMERICAN FIELD HOSPITAL A field hospital of the type used in the American army has just been exhibited in Paris. It is due to the generosity of the Fahnestock family of New York. It consists of twentytwo khaki-colored canvas tents. Eight conical tents are •for the use of the staff. Six oblong tents are to be used for the wounded; each tent can receive eighteen so that there is a capacity of 108 wounded. Five hospital tents have a double covering, a circulation of air between the two layers of canvas maintaining an even temperature within the tents. Three of these five are for operation rooms; the fourth is used as a pharmacy and the fifth is for the reserve medical appliances. Three tents are intended each to accommodate two officers. These twenty-two tents and their contents are placed on four trucks furnished by the French government. To this unit, which is about to go to the front, are attached ten large automobiles belonging to the American hospital of Neuilly. Each of these cars can carry four or five wounded men sitting and three who are unable to sit up. The great utility of this ambulance will be in seeking out the wounded at the first aid post behind the line of fire and transporting them rapidly after the first dressings to the stations." books.google.com/books?id=0uwBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA2152&... www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&f... More photos of the hospital: books.google.com/books?id=Mk4fAQAAMAAJ&dq=fahnestock%...

The original Charles Schwab.

Charles Michael Schwab (1862-1939) is one of the greatest entrepreneurs in US history. Thomas Edison once referred to him as the “master hustler.”

Early in his life, Charles was a laborer in a Pennsylvania company known as Edgar Thompson Steel Works, which was owned by steel tycoon Andrew Carnegie. Charles ascended the ranks there, becoming assistant manager in the early 1880s, and manager in 1887.

Five years later, Andrew Carnegie asked him to restore relationships between labor and management after a severe strike at the Homestead steel plant. Charles not only succeeding in doing so, but he also dramatically and impressively improved the plant’s efficiency. This made way for his rise in Carnegie’s steel empire, and by 1897, Charles became president of the Carnegie Steel Company.

Then in 1901, he teamed with financier J.P. Morgan, and combined and consolidated several competing steel companies (including Carnegie’s) in order to form a new powerhouse called United States Steel Corporation.

Charles also became the new company’s president, but he resigned two years later due to conflicts with Morgan and the company’s directors.

Charles then devoted his efforts to a smaller steel company of his called Bethlehem Steel, which he had a controlling interest in since 1901.

A masterful innovator and motivator, Charles was able to make his company one of the most powerful steel-manufacturers in the world, mainly through efficiency improvements and a merger with the U.S. Shipbuilding Corporation.

The company reaped huge profits during World War I, supplying steel for military uses.

By then, Charles was very well known as a steel tycoon with a lavish lifestyle, risk-taking style, and rumored unethical business tactics.

By the 1920s his fortune was worth around $200 million, but that fortune slowly drained due to factors such as his spending habits, a string of bad investments, and the Great Depression. He died broke in 1939.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_M._Schwab

The American Ship Lines had 3 sailings a week from Liverpool to Philadelphia and in the year 1882 alone, 17,342 passengers arrived from Liverpool. The line had four ships that traveled "via" Liverpool and Queenstown to Philadelphia. They were called Kensington, Southwark, Haverford and Merion. The Merion is the ship that carried our Cafferty and Boland ancestors to America.

All in all, the ship brought in around 20,000 immigrants each year between 1880 and 1910 from England/Ireland.
More about the Philadelphia: www.norwayheritage.com/p_ship.asp?sh=phil1

According to the experts at the Steelnavy.com message forum, this is a Cressy-class cruiser, either HMS Bacchante or more likely HMS Euryalus: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Euryalus_(1901) Wikipedia: Euryalus assisted the landings at Cape Helles. The 1st Battalion of the Lancashire Fusiliers were embarked in Euryalus and the battleship HMS Implacable which took up positions off the beach. The troops transferred to 32 cutters at around 4 am. Euryalus closed in on the beach at around 5 am whilst Implacable moved off to land troops and provide covering fire at X beach, and opened fire on the defences.
Part of the notorious Gallipoli campaign: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedd-el-Bahr

Ahmed Cemal, known as Cemal Pasha (former transcription Djemal Pasha): see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djemal_Pasha Bruno Traugott Karl TROMMER (-PASCHA) was a german officer who served in the ottoman army (www.lexikon-deutschegenerale.de/t_pr.html ). Pasha has in this context the meaning of „General“.

Djemal Pacha, aka Djemal Pasha, Cemal Paşa was a key figure in the Ottoman empire in the early 20th Century, part of a triumvirate that ruled the empire during WWI. He also headed a number of Ottoman military campaigns, and was implicated in the Armenian Genocide. He was assassinated in 1922 as part of a campaign to kill those deemed responsible for the Armenian Genocide. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djemal_Pasha In his memoirs, readable online, he defended himself against these charges. archive.org/details/memoriesofturkis00cemarich Trommer Pasha is mentioned as one of the few German officers fighting with the Turks at Gallipoli, (CO of the XIV Corps), so perhaps this is where the photo was taken. Here's a brief biography of A. Bertram Samuels, who may be the A. B. Samuels in the photo above. His age seems to be appropriate.

TYPHUS, WAR'S DREAD ALLY, BEATEN; News of Dr. Harry Plotz's Vaccine Discovery Comes When Europe Faces Awful Ravages from Scourge. April 18, 1915 The announcement of the discovery of a protective vaccine against typhus fever, the dreadful scourge that dogs the heels of war, following closely upon the confirmation of the germ origin of the disease by repeated demonstrations of a distinct causative agent visible under the microscope, is but another instance of the accuracy of modern laboratory methods and the continual progress of medical science. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20C1EFE385C1373...

books.google.com/books/about/The_Etiology_of_Thyphus_Exan... indicates that Baehr was a colleague of Plotz. Another copy, at archive.org/stream/etiologyoftyphus00plotrich#page/n1/mod... indicates that "The etiology of typhus exanthematicus" was first published in July 1915 in the Journal of Infectious Diseases. Authors were Harry Plotz, George Baehr, and Peter K. Olitsky.

NYT of June 28, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50F11FD3B5C13738... reported that Plotz and Baehr sailed on the Themistocles the previous day for Serbia for a year, armed with 20,000 tubes of typhus vaccine.
More about Dr. Harry Plotz: www.sciencephoto.com/media/227849/enlarge His January, 1947 obituary is here: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70B17FF3E5A1B7B...

About the ship: THEMISTOCLES 1911 11,231 gross tons, length 500.6ft x beam 62.3ft, one funnel, two masts, twin screw, speed 15 knots. Accommodation for 103-1st, 400-3rd and 500-emigrant class passengers in the 'tween decks. Built by Harland & Wolff, Belfast, she was launched for the Aberdeen Line on 22nd Sep.1910 and started her maiden voyage from London to Sydney on 16th Feb.1911. Between 1914-1919 she was used as a troopship and resumed commercial sailings to Australia on 20th July 1920. From 1928 she came under the management of White Star Line and operated London - Brisbane on the Aberdeen Line - White Star - Blue Funnel joint service. Transferred to Shaw, Savill & Albion Line in 1932 after the collapse of White Star, she started Liverpool - Australia sailings in June. During WWII she remained in commercial service and was eventually laid up in 1946 after 79 voyages to Australia and was scrapped at Dalmuir the following year. [Merchant Fleets by Duncan Haws, Aberdeen Line] www.theshipslist.com/ships/descriptions/ShipsT-U.shtml

This, and another 14 Bain pictures, seem to be of the 1915 Poughkeepsie Regatta, which began on June 28, 1915 on the Hudson River. It was the premier collegiate rowing event of its era and attracted huge crowds along the river. Competing that year were Cornell, Columbia, Syracuse, U. of Penn, and Stanford. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E04E6D81631E733A... The other Bain photos of the event www.flickr.com/search/?w=8623220@N02&q=1915%20poughke...

More about the Regatta: "The IRA [Intercollegiate Rowing Association] was founded by Cornell University, Columbia University, and the University of Pennsylvania. These universities wanted to form an association in order to hold a race every year in which all of the top rowing schools in the country could compete. They chose the Hudson River, outside of Poughkeepsie, as the location to hold the race. It was one of the few places that had a straightaway that was four miles long. Only a single race was run to determine the championship—winner take all. An even more significant difference is that it was a four mile long race. This fact set the Regatta apart from all other crew races that have ever been held. It is the reason why the IRA Regatta became as prestigious as it did, and why the crew team that won was nationally regarded as the best of the best. The Poughkeepsie Regatta quickly became one of the greatest sporting events to watch in the country, and put Poughkeepsie on the map. Every year tens of thousands of spectators would come pouring into Poughkeepsie to watch the races. They covered the shores next to the river, many waiting all day, picnicking on blankets, to ensure they had a good view. The railroad tracks on the west side of the river had a flatbed train which held grandstands from which spectators could watch the race. As the crews rowed up the river, the train would keep pace with them, giving the people on board the best view possible. Hundreds of boats, yachts, and occasionally even Navy destroyers sailed to Poughkeepsie, and moored on the sides of the river to watch the event. The town of Poughkeepsie came alive on the day of the Regatta, with parades, bands, vendors, and banners. In addition, colorful pennants displaying the school colors of all the participants were flying everywhere. The Regatta was extensively covered by newspaper reporters, and as time went on it was even broadcast over local and national radio stations. But the crowds, the cheers, the reporters, parades, and pennants were not the reasons why the Regatta became so intensely popular, the explanation lay in the physical feats of the crew teams. To race at full-speed for four miles required such a breathtaking amount of strength, skill, and endurance that it was awe-inspiring to watch." library.marist.edu/archives/regatta/history.html
I think you're right bior, this is probably Jim Rice. He would have been coach during the 1915 Poughkeepsie Regatta.

The Poughkeepsie Bridge (sometimes known as the Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge, the Poughkeepsie-Highland Railroad Bridge, the High Bridge, or, since October 3, 2009, the Walkway Over the Hudson State Historic Park) is a steel cantilever bridge spanning the Hudson River between Poughkeepsie, New York on the east bank and Highland, New York on the west bank. In the autumn of 1913 John Reed was sent to Mexico by the Metropolitan Magazine to report the Mexican Revolution. He shared the perils of Pancho Villa's army for four months, present with Villa's Constitutional(must say Constitutonalist) Army (under Venustiano Carranza who was its "First or Principal Chief" as he was known) when it defeated Federal forces at Torreón, opening the way for its advance on Mexico City. Reed's time with the Villistas resulted in a series of outstanding magazine articles that brought Jack a national reputation as a war correspondent. Reed deeply sympathized with the plight of the peons and vehemently opposed American intervention, which came shortly after he left. Jack adored Villa, while Carranza left him cold. Jack's Mexican reports were later republished in book form as Insurgent Mexico, which appeared in 1914. In www.nevadaobserver.com/Mexican%20Revolution%20-%20People/... Back to back with the driver, wearing his mounted police Stetson and www.nevadaobserver.com/Mexican%20Revolution%20-%20People/... you can see Pancho Villa and "Juanito" Reed (as Pancho rebaptized him).

John Reed and Boardman Robinson went in 1915 to Eastern Europe and Russia, where they were arrested. They were gathering material for a book that Reed was to write and Robinson illustrate. That book, The War In Eastern Europe, was published the following year.

Mabel Dodge, one of Reed's lovers, described him in a way that makes this portrait come to life:
"His olive green eyes glowed softly, his high forehead was like a baby's with light brown curls rolling away from it and two spots of shining light on his temples, making him lovable. His chin was the best... the real poet's jawbone... eyebrows always lifted... generally breathless!"

She was launched on 19 June 1915, making it about fifteen months from keel-laying to launch. In the meantime, the ship was named after the newest state in the union The New York Times estimated that 75,000 people attended the launch, including John Purroy Mitchel, the Mayor of New York City, George W. P. Hunt, the governor of Arizona, and many high-ranking military officials. Several warships were also nearby, including many of the new dreadnoughts which had already entered service (Florida, Utah, Wyoming, Arkansas, New York, and Texas). Esther Ross, the daughter of an Arizona pioneer family, was given the honors of ship sponsor and christening. To acknowledge a ban on alcohol recently passed by the state legislature, the state's governor decided that two bottles would be used: one full of sparkling wine from Ohio, and another filled with water from the Roosevelt Dam.

NYT of February 7, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E1EFE395B17738... reports that Edward N. Breitung had acquired the German steamship Dacia. This was an issue that led to congressional debates, with some arguing that such purchases would entangle the US in the war. Later in February 1915, the ship was captured by the French and was unable to immediately prove that she was a neutral ship. books.google.com/books?id=zlPjhO5WA5gC&pg=PA1016&... has more on the legal case that followed the capture. A picture of Mr. Breitung is at: www.pictorialgems.com/1915-Captain-Wood-Durward-Mr-Edward...
Mrs. Breitung was an active philanthropist and member of New York society. See search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&gss=angs-d...

The 1915 U.S. Open was the 21st U.S. Open. The golf tournament was held June 17–18, 1915, at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, New Jersey. Another forgotten scandal of 1915: Mrs. Ruth Taylor Conlin and young Donald Clapham (both were under 21) were accused of breaking into closed cottages in Sea Cliff, Long Island, and robbing them, mostly for the adventure. Mrs. Conlin was a society "belle," and Clapham was her tango partner. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-06-19/ed-... news.google.com/newspapers?id=vEQdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NkkEA... Mrs. Conlin had eloped as a teenager with a chauffeur (a la Downton Abbey!); the marriage did not last long, but the Conlins were not yet legally divorced during Ruth and Donald's spree.

William Charles Flynn was a perfect "eugenic baby"--winner in at least fourteen Better Baby contests sponsored by eugenically-oriented groups. He was in the news at this tender age (37 months in March 1915), because his mother found him a good eugenic match for a future wife: 17-month-old "perfect" baby Alene Calvert Houck, herself the winner of six better baby contests. Both children had scored a perfect 100 on measurements intended to set an ideal. "The mothers are convinced that fate has thrown their children together for some great purpose, but they have agreed that they will not resort to any form of coercion in shaping the future of their children." news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19150327&... trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/60066021 The Trove link includes the respective physical measurements of William and Alene. Best I can figure, he did not, in fact, marry Miss Houck.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] It's not a diaper, it's a jockstrap, designed to cover only the genitalia for the purpose of displaying the body. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jelon71] The whole idea of eugenics is creepy, yes. But contests for good-looking children have not gone away. Presently the U.S. hosts child beauty contests. The people running those shows brought it out here to Australia, and Australians said, "Get out of here. That's too creepy and we think not a very healthy, sane way to treat children, dressing them up and sexualizing them." Here is just one newspaper article that sums up the reaction down here. For anyone who thinks this photo is great---no, it is not. This is a terrible photo, a particularly bad one in which not only the highlights have blown out, but the upper mid tones have blown out too. Either the photographer who took the picture got the exposure wrong, or the negative was developed for less time than the film and film speed required, or the person who made the print in the darkroom was a moron. From a technical standpoint, this is a bad photo.

From www.nyhistory.org/node/45765 Elizabeth Callender Stevens was the daughter of Francis B. Stevens. She was married to her second cousin Richard Stevens (1868-1919) on November 11, 1893, in Hoboken, New Jersey. Mrs. Stevens married her second husband, Josef Forman, a Czechoslovakian diplomat, in England on October 12, 1925. The marriage ended in divorce in 1927. librarycollections.stevens.edu/items/show/591 Indicates that she and Richard Stevens had four children.

A 1908 Social Register books.google.com/books?id=GBQMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA535&l... suggests that both Mrs. Richard Stevens, nee Elizabeth Callender Stevens, and her daughter, went by "Elsie". So another picture in this set is probably her debutante daughter.
Columbia alumni news, Volume 10 books.google.com/books?id=n44hAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA981&l... indicates that Richard Stevens died of pneumonia on May 18, 1919

NYT of Oct 1925 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A12FF39551B7A... carries the announcement of her wedding to Josef Forman, "MRS. ELSIE STEVENS TO WED IN ENGLAND; Wealthy Castle Point Widow to Marry Today Josef Forman of Czechoslovakia, a Writer." NYT of Feb 22, 1927 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3081EF83F5F147A... announces their divorce.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Thank you

The Thatchers lived on Park Avenue, with a second home at Bayville, Long Island, and had several children. Their son John Jr. was a vice president at Paine Webber. Their daughter Katherine Sands Thatcher married Richard Porter Leach, who served as director of programming at Lincoln Center. She was still alive in 1987. Looks like they put handwritten headlines above the entrance. The statue sat across from City Hall in front of the Tribure Building at Nassau and Spruce Streets. This statue was eventually moved to City Hall Park and is there today. www.nycgovparks.org/parks/cityhallpark/highlights/13314 A view from City Hall of the Tribune Building (an architecturaly important building), now demolished, in 1966: lcweb2.loc.gov/pnp/habshaer/ny/ny0400/ny0435/photos/11992... Wikipedia says the building was demolished in 1955, but that's obviously incorrect, based on the LOC photo which is clearly from the mid-60's. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Tribune_Building Other sources correctly state that it was demolished in 1966 to make way for a Pace College building. www.nytimes.com/1988/05/15/realestate/in-the-new-york-reg...
Statue here is not the one in City Hall Park; it's the one in Greely Square Park. http://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/greeleysquarepark/highlights/13313

better link: www.nycgovparks.org/parks/greeleysquarepark/highlights/13313 Interestingly enough, the NY Parks site is misleading. There are two similar Greeley statues. For some reason they accurately describe the one pictured above as in City Hall Park, but they picture it on the Greeley Park page of their site. On the City Hall Park page, they accurately describe the statue there (pictured above in the Bain photo) but they mistakenly picture the Greeley Square statue. www.nycgovparks.org/parks/cityhallpark/highlights/13314 The most obvious difference is that Greeley has a newspaper spread out on his right thigh in the City Hall Park statue, and has a book hanging down in his right hand in the Greeley Square one. maps.google.com/maps?q=greeley+square,+new+york&ll=40...

Then there's the question of why this photo is in the June, 1915 news stream. On June 13, 1915, the N.Y. Times published a story about the building's owners wanting to rent the corner space to a drugstore, and needed to move the statue to do so. It's a wry, tongue in cheek story, which notes that after the shoeshine stand was installed to the left of Greeley, it looked like he was waiting in line for a shine. The statue moved across the street into the park eventually, but the place was not determined when the article was written. It was suggested, though, that, the statue (in the famous words of Greeley) "go west ,young man", and it did. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10D13FF3D551273... Also dating the picture are the news headlines above the statue. It looks like they had someone up there on a wooden platform painting them for the passersby. These headlines, about the Wilson diplomatic note that caused his Secretary of State to resign, the turmoil in Mexico, and the Italian offensive on Trento (Trent) are all stories in the Tribune's edition of June 11, 1915: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-06-11/ed-...

Lois Irene Kimsey Marshall (born Lois Irene Kimsey; May 9, 1873 — January 6, 1958) was the wife of Thomas R. Marshall, who served as the 28th Vice President of the United States from 1913 to 1921. During her husband's tenure she held the unofficial position of the Second Lady of the United States. She served also as First Lady of Indiana during her husband's Governorship (1909–1913). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lois_Irene_Marshall

Barbara Cainrcross Rutherfurd (1895-1939), debutante of the 1915-16 season. Apparently her bedroom was copied from a Renaissance painting of St. Ursula (there's also a 1921 photo of her at this link): aestheteslament.blogspot.com/2011_09_28_archive.html Her mother was Anne Harriman Sands Rutherfurd Vanderbilt. Her stepfather was William K. Vanderbilt Sr. (whose ex-wife Alva is also in this week's uploads). Barbara married twice--to Cyril Hatch in 1916 (divorced 1921), and to Winfield J. Nicholls in 1924 (divorced 1927, and in Reno 1930). She (and her mother and sister) were involved in a cult called "the Mystic Order of Tantricks," run by someone called "Oom the Omnipotent." Her children, twins, were born five months into her second marriage; she was apparently not involved in their upbringing (or even in choosing their names). Her second husband claimed she was a lunatic and sought to have their marriage annulled. Barbara died at age 44, at Cannes, France. news.google.com/newspapers?id=60ZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CQ4EA... Her brother Winthrop Rutherfurd married (as his second wife) Lucy Page Mercer--the mistress of FDR. Winthrop and Lucy's only child was named Barbara. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucy_Page_Mercer_Rutherfurd

The grave of Winthrop Rutherfurd and Lucy Mercer Rutherfurd -- with notes about her scandalous relationship with FDR:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23021987@N06/2576591740/]

From what I can see, this Augustowa (one of several places in Poland with the name) is at roughly 53.85N,23.02E, south of Suwalki, southeast of Olecko (aka Marggrabowa) and northwest of Grodno (now Hrodna, in Belarus). www.travelmath.com/cities-near/Augustow,+Poland
Wonderful  capture..

This photo was taken in Augustów (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August%C3%B3w) in former Russian barracks, probably in February 1915 during or after Second Battle of the Masurian Lakes (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Battle_of_the_Masurian_Lakes). Russian 20th Army Corps was surrounded by the Germans in the Augustow Forest. Barrack's buildings still exist: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Former_barracks_in_Au..., but I'm not sure, if exactly this from the photo. This image was released several times as German military postcards. There are many others German photos showing fights in this region.

According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masurian_Lake_District "The Masurian Lake District or Masurian Lakeland (Polish: Pojezierze Mazurskie; German: Masurische Seenplatte) is a lake district in northeastern Poland ", "The Lakeland extends roughly 290 km (180 mi) eastwards from the lower Vistula to the Poland–Russia border" and "In modern times, while part of the German Empire, it was the location of the First Battle of the Masurian Lakes (1914) and the Second Battle of the Masurian Lakes (1915) during World War I."
This was a very bad patch of land to be around in the winter of 1915.
More information about masurian lake district you can find on: www.e-mazury.com.pl

This photo could be taken in former Russian barracks in Augustów or Suwałki. These towns are located in Suwalszczyzna - a region next to Masuria, on the east. Current view (in Augustów): commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Former_barracks_in_August...

"Notice by the faculty that five of the best oarsmen in the freshman eight have been placed on probation in their studies came as a shock to the Yale rowing officials." Boston Evening Transcript 13 May 1915. news.google.com/newspapers?id=GUwnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7AMGA...

The Yale banner and pot pourri, Volume 8 books.google.com/books?id=JC3OAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA205&l... lists the same freshman crew as racing Harvard on June 25, 1915. Yale won. The report of the regatta in the Harvard Crimson is at www.thecrimson.com/article/1915/9/24/yale-gained-aquatic-...

www.corbisimages.com/stock-photo/rights-managed/U28257INP... could be taken at the same time. If so, this is on June 10, 1915, "At New Training Quarters Of Yale Oarsmen at Gales Ferry On The Thames: Yale freshman crew. Left to right: Lawrence, stroke; Coombe, 7; Coleman, 6; MacNaughton, 5; Glover, 4; Converse, 3; Lovejoy, 2; Rockefeller, bow, and Lashar, cox." One of the orderings must be wrong. The Bain photo has the names (apart from the cox) in the opposite order.

www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=52847363 appears to be anothe of these young men, Ensign Leslie Malcolm MacNaughton. Converse appears to be Rob Roy Stearns Converse. books.google.com/books?id=xwIcAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA10-PA108&... suggests that the cox is Thomas Holmes Lashar who applied for a patent for method to prevent tarnish on silver. His father Thomas. B Lashar was a designer of silver flatware.

Harvard and Yale raced twice in 1915. Once on May 17, 1915 on the Charles River at Harvard and again on June 25, 1915 on the Connecticut River in New London, Connecticut. The buildings shown are in Gales Ferry, Connecticut. The original boathouse can be seen in a 1910 postcard. Since it is Connecticut the date must be June 25, 1915. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gales_Ferry,_Connecticut books.google.com/books?id=it8TAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA147 [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8056650990/in/photostream/]
I'm sure this photo will end up being the basis for a Wes Anderson film one day...

In 1914 the Harvard second eight won the Henley: www.thecrimson.com/article/1968/3/15/history-of-harvard-s... www.thecrimson.com/article/1914/10/23/student-council-off... The older members of the 1914 team went to war soon after the victory. Oarsmen on that team that were still there in 1915 were Henry Stump Middendorf of Baltimore, and Henry Hixon Meyer of Kansas City. Meyer went on to earn a law degree; Middendorf became a banker.

The Harvard Crimson reported on the 1915 regatta www.thecrimson.com/article/1915/9/24/yale-gained-aquatic-... and gave fuller names: "Harvard second eight.--Stroke, F. W. Busk '16; 7, H. T. Meyer '15; 6, H. S. Middendorf '16; 5, W. Richardson '17; 4, J. Talcott, Jr., '16; 3, A. Potter '17; 2, R. R. Brown '17; bow, F. H. L. Whitmarsh '16; cox., A. A. Cameron '17. " As pennylrichardsca noted, it should be Meyer, not Meter.

worldconnect.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET... identifies Frederick Wadsworth Busk as being Harvard '16. A brief early bio in a Harvard Class of '16 report is at books.google.com/books?id=KscnAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA52&lp... An obituary (in 1970) is at: archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=1840&Keyword=&am...

Talcott would appear to be James Talcott, Jr. According to the Harvard Graduates Magazine, /books?id=TitYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA168&lpg=PA168 he married Mary Stoddard Johnson on April 14, 1917 in Boston. A genealogy page is at genforum.genealogy.com/cgi-bin/print.cgi?talcott::155.html
Henry Stump Middendorf died in 1972. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=83274525 His wife was Anne Eliot Bradley.

On June 8, 1915. a Chinese trade delegation visited Thomas Edison in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, New Jersey, where he lived. There were 18 in the delegation, with three secretaries. Some of them are indentifed in this new york times account: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9902E6D81338E6...

Pennyrichardsca found this account of the trip in Electrical World Magazine: "The commission spent the entire day of June 8 at the plant of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., traveling in a special train directly to the establishment. The members of the commission were received by Mr. Edison in the laboratory and were then taken by Mr. M. R. Hutchison, chief engineer, on a tour of the buildings. The morning was spent in the Edison Storage Battery Company building. The members of the commission and the large party accompanying them were entertained at lunch and afterward viewed educational, comic and talking moving pictures. The guests also saw a demonstration of the machine that records telephone conversations." books.google.com/books?id=Z2sfAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22J.%20H.%...
Thanks to both of you for this excellent research into the visit by the trade commission. We'll add some of this information to the record the next time we update.

Their father: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constantine_I_of_Greece Their mother: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophia_of_Prussia Constantine and Sophia had six children: George (1890-1947): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_II_of_Greece Alexander (1893-1920): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_of_Greece Helen (1896-1982): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_of_Greece_and_Denmark Paul (1901-1964): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_of_Greece Irene (1904-1974): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Irene,_Duchess_of_Aosta Katherine (1913-2007): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Katherine_of_Greece_and_De... This was in the days of March Inaugurals. Woodrow Wilson was inaugurated as President on March 4, 1913 in Washington, and Williams Jennings Bryan en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan served as his Secretary of State from 1913-1915.
Another Bain photo was taken at about the same time: Bryan resigned as Secretary of State in June, 1915, which probably accounts for its inclusion in the 1915 news stream.

Trieste (now in Italy) was an important port for the Austro-Hungarian Empire. See histclo.com/essay/war/ww1/cou/w1c-ita.html for an outline of Italy's participation in WWI The Italians tried repeatedly to reach and capture Trieste over the next two years. Britain and France persuade Italy to join the war in May 1915, with the lure of Austrian territory on the northeast Adriatic, including Trieste.

See NYT of April 4, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E12FA395B1773... for an essay on the possible "reconstruction" of Poland. It begins, "In spite of its vagueness, the Grand Duke Nicholas's proclamation justifies the most sanguine hopes. This has been recognized not only by all the Poles whom it has reached, those of Russian Poland, and the three million Polish refugees who live in America, but moreover, all the Allies have interpreted it as a genuine promise that Poland would be territorially and politically re-constructed." I think the "proclamation" mentioned is probably one from the previous year in which Nicholas asked for support from Poles in return for autonomy. Jeannette Gourd and Helen Hoadley were both bridesmaids at the 1921 wedding of Mary Sloan Colt and Louis Curtis Jr., at Garrison NY. Helen A. Hoadley and "Jeanne" Gourd were also both bridesmaids at the wedding of Henry Calhoun Taylor and Jeannette Jennings, in 1917. Think these are the same girls: Helen A. Hoadley (b. 1897), daughter of Mary Eliot Betts (1871-1948) and Russell H. Hoadley Jr. (1872-1942), sister of Sheldon Eliot Hoadley (1894-1918, died in WWI), and Louise Russell Hoadley James. Her grandfather was Frederic H. Betts. Her photo is here associated with an amateur play in 1916: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-12-14/ed-... Jeannette Gourd was the daughter of Henry Eugene Gourd (President of the French Chamber of Commerce in New York) and Emilie Noel Gourd; her older sisters were Helene (Mrs. Hoguet), Renee (Mrs. de Milhau), Yvonne, and Gabrielle. She also had brothers Marcel and Louis. This passenger list has her age 9 in 1907, so she'd be born c1898: www.ellisisland.org/shipping/FormatTripPass.asp?sship=La%...

According to the Spokesman-Review of Nov 12, 1912 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19121112&... "Miss Adelaide Cannon, the pretty daughter of Mrs. Theodore P Frelinghuysen, is the latest society beauty to attract Vincent Astor, the heir to $100,000,000, and according to rumors that come from the neighbourhood of Tuxedo Park, his attentions to Miss Cannon are looked upon as serious. Young Astor has recently become interested in outdoor sports, possibly because of Miss Cannon, who is a splendid horsewoman and a very accomplished girl. She is especially interested in amateur photography, and takes her camera everywhere with her." She has the camera in this picture. She married in 1916 The [New York] sun., September 24, 1916, SECTION 3, Image 21 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-09-24/ed-... Adelaide Cannon's marriage to Henry Luden of Holland has been set for October 28 in Tuxedo. The Washington times., December 01, 1918, NATIONAL EDITION, The American Weekly Section, Image 31 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1918-12-01/ed-... has a long piece on George Henry Warren, to whom Miss Cannon had been engaged, with a picture of her as horsewoman (and as Mrs Henry Luden). In society registers e.g., books.google.com/books?id=ysc3AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA233&l... and some newspaper articles, she is Miss Elizabeth Adelaide Cannon of Tuxedo Park, NY

NYT of September 16, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A17F73E5E1373... has the engagement announcement of Adelaide to Henry Luden. Henry Luden was drowned in Holland in July 1924 and she married again, according to NYT of Dec 26, 1928. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30E10F63855167A... "Mr. and Mrs. Le Grand B. Cannon have announced the marriage of his sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Adelaide Luden, to Edgar Leonard of this city, which took place on Nov. 24 in the American Church, Rue de Berri, Paris."

I think this is a mistranscription of the middle initial and a misspelling of the last name, and this is a picture of Mrs. John H. (Herbert) Ballantine. Her husband (1864-1946) was a grandson of Peter Ballantine, who founded the famous brewery, Peter Ballantine & Sons, in Newark, New Jersey . After leaving the brewery business, he moved to the Neptune Meter Co. and became president. There were two Mrs. John H. Ballantines. He married the first , Lois Wilgus Ballantine, in 1890. She died on December 24, 1919. I'm guessing that is who is pictured here. books.google.com/books?id=S5E-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1066&... The second Mrs. B. was Gertrude Drake Ballantine (1869-1958). There was a son, John Holme Ballantine, from the first marriage, born 1892. It is possible this is his wife, as this seems to be a much younger woman than Lois Ballantine must have been in 1915, after 25 years of marriage.

I was coming to the same conclusion -- about the spelling and middle initial. The question then becomes whether this woman is the same as the bride pictured top left of the New-York tribune, January 22, 1915, Page 11 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-01-22/ed-... If so, she is the former Helen Ridgley Morgan and Mrs. John Holme Ballantine. It's possible, but I'm not certain.

She IS Helen Ridgley Morgan!. This photo is her engagement photo and was used by the New York Herald. See fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... The engagement appears to have been only a few days before the wedding.

They appear to have had two children. John Holme Ballantine Jr, was killed in WWII Death announcement on Dec 10, 1944 in NYT select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E1EFF3C5D177B... [subscription probably required] His sister was Helen Ridgley Ballantine. She married Wentworth Smith on June 3, 1939 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40812F83A58127A... [subscription probably required]

You nailed it. The Times story says the wedding wasn't intended to be so soon, but Ballantine was called away on business to Pasadena, so they moved it up. She had just had her debut the month before. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB091FFD3E5C13738...

Despite her social popularity, she was still Miss Almy Gilford when she married Donald Jones in 1962. She was his third wife. See NYT of April 27, 1962 (subscription needed) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10711FF3D5C177A9...

On 26 May 1915, TEXAS responded to an emergency call to rescue passengers aboard the damaged Holland-American ship RYNDAM (RIJNDAM in Dutch). The RYNDAM and the Norwegian steam JOESPH J CUNEO collided in a dense fog off Nantucket Shoals, off the Rhode Island shore. Racing through the fog with the SOUTH CAROLINA, the ships arrived at the location and rescued 230 passengers. With the passengers rescued, both ships escorted the damaged RYNDAM on a19 hour move to New York City. From this website www.bb35library.usstexasbb35.com/history/1915-1917-aprall...
The Holland America Line is still running cruises and has a new Ryndham. www.hollandamerica.com/cruise-vacation-onboard/Ryndam

The brass plaque to the left of the door says "Albertina Rasch Dance Studio". Rasch (1891 - 1967) was a dancer and choreographer, based in New York. She was also married to the composer Dmitri Tiomkin. This and the four unidentified room photos that precede it are identified on an Historical Ziegfeld site as being of Rasch's dance studio. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albertina_Rasch historicalziegfeld.multiply.com/photos/album/297# From a biographical sketch on the official Dmitri Tomkin website, comes the following: "Eager to impart her experience and knowledge to teachers, other dancers, and children, she settled in New York and opened the Albertina Rasch Dance Studio in October 1923. With its inspiring view of the Hudson River, the studio offered private and group lessons in ballet and interpretative dance. Rasch’s strict regimen, including body alignment and breathing exercises based on her own European training, set her dancers apart from the typical chorus-line girls who populated the New York stage. The rigorous training program gave Rasch’s dancers the stamina necessary to endure long vaudeville days and nights and, later, filming that required take after take." www.dimitritiomkin.com/biography/albertina-rasch/ These pictures therefore must date from October, 1923 or after.

A section from a biography of Jeanette Macdonald starting near the bottom of books.google.com/books?id=ojOxCgHZLpUC&pg=PA47&lp... discusses the influence of Rasch on Macdonald, mentioning a location for Rasch's studio in the Steinway Building on West 57th St., but not giving a date. 109-113 West 57th Street is where Steinway Hall (built in 1925) is located. But it would not have had a view of the Hudson and the architecture doesn't match. Presumably Rasch opened her first studio somewhere else, on the West Side of New York City. Although buildings from this vintage are still found on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side, the midtown area along the Hudson, which would have been closer to the theatre district, looks as though it has been completely torn up and re-developed. books.google.com/books?id=4iL0a2rQzsgC&pg=PA146&l... is a 1931 directory of schools of the theatre arts. It has the Rasch studio at 113 West 57th, but does have other dance studios on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side. However, a trip between 73rd and 88th using Google's Streetview didn't find this building.
Another site with extensive info on Rasch is songbook1.wordpress.com/pp/fx/features-2-older-2/albertin...

The Washington herald., February 22, 1920, Page 7, Image 21 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1920-02-22/ed-... has an ad (B.F. Keith's is in large letters) for a show in which Rasch appears with her "society pupils as coryphees." So she clearly taught before 1923.

ok, I think I've found it, in the New York Times on October 21, 1923: *** ALBERTINA RASCH Now preparing her Company for her CONCERT TOUR has opened her DANCE STUDIO 344 W. 72d St., New York City. Tel. Endicott 7589 CLASS — PRIVATE LESSON —BALLET INTERPRETIVE—DANCES ARRANGED. New York recitals in the early Spring. We can place pupils when qualifying *** So, the building is still there, the Chatsworth Apartments, built in 1904. It looks like W. 72d St. used to end on a bluff over the Hudson, but it was redesigned into onramps and offramps from Riverside Blvd. and the Henry Hudson parkway. Still pretty nice location, but not the dreamy little corner it once was. If you look up to the very top on Google Street View, there are slanted windows that match the ones in the pictures of the studio rooms. maps.google.com/maps?q=344+w.+72d+street,+ny&ll=40.78... If you have a spare $150 Million, it might still be for sale: online.wsj.com/article/SB10000872396390444318104577587540... And here is an analysis of The Chatsworth, done in connection with its landmark designation: www.landmarkwest.org/maps_and_data/Designation%20Reports/...

Big Tim Sullivan and his wife Helen Fitzgerald Sullivan adopted Aida (or Ada) as a 2-year-old foundling, but there were strong suspicions that she was Tim's biological daughter (he had several children by various women). After Helen died, and Tim was declared mentally incompetent, Aida lived with her Fitzgerald grandparents. Aida was not named in Tim's will in 1913, so she sued, and eventually won a sizeable settlement from the estate. Tim Sullivan's wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_Sullivan She became a performer with Ziegfeld Follies, and was briefly married to a William Epstein.

Booth Tarkington was married to poet Laurel Louisa Fletcher (d. 1923) from 1902-1911, and married to Susannah Kiefer Robinson from 1912 until his death in 1946.

id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n91006431.html suggests that his second wife, who was 42 when they married, might usually have spelled her name with a single "n." From the finding aid to her papers at Indiana Historical Socety www.indianahistory.org/our-collections/collection-guides/... "Susanah Tarkington (1870-1966) was born Susanah Kiefer in Dayton, Ohio. In the 1890s she was married for five years to Temple A. Robinson of London, then divorced. In 1912 she married Booth Tarkington, by then well-known as a playwright and novelist. He had previously married and been divorced from Louise Fletcher, daughter of banker Stoughton A. Fletcher."

www.tomasinoblog.com/2009/06/19/ima-journal-louisa-fletcher/ shows a portrait of Laurel Louisa Fletcher in 1912. From that I would say that this picture is definitely of a different woman and thus his second wife, Susanah. The blog has contributions from Louisa's family. Though officially allied with Germany and Austria-Hungary, Italy entered the war on May 23, 1915 on the side of England, France and Russia. This led to huge, peaceful demonstrations in New York's Italian neighborhoods. The Italian Consulate was at that time at 226 Lafayette St, on Cleveland Place in Little Italy. According to a New York Times account, it was one of the busiest places in New York that week, owing to the fact that it kept track of the 200,000 Italian army and navy reservists in New York. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30617FA385C1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B1EF83A5A1773... Both buildings in the picture are still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=226+lafayette+st+nyc&ll=40.722...

And a year later, during the Citizens Preparedness Parade (buildings at far right):

A Miss Beatrice Williams, 24, of Great Britain, was among the survivors of the Lusitania: www.rmslusitania.info/people/lusitania-survivors/ Mr. George Benjamin Lane, 26, was the only Lane listed among the survivors. www.rmslusitania.info/people/second-cabin/george-lane/ Lane and Williams seem to have been part of a Welsh musical group, the Gwent Royal Welsh Singers, returning to Wales on the Lusitania. Found this about her experience in the sinking: "Preston-Smith was with Beatrice Williams and they ran back downstairs to get lifejackets. Miss Williams was placed in a boat and told to get out again. "The ship was listing so heavily," she said, "that I had to jump. Mr. Preston-Smith jumped with me and I was picked up and put on a raft." www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/lusitania-lest-we-forget-2....

I think you are right about G.B. Lane. A detailed account of the actions of the Gwent Choir after the sinking is in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle of May 30, 1915 . I'm not sure Williams was in the choir, but instead escaped with Lane, who was. She isn't mentioned in the account: "Dewi Michael, the director of the singers, was one of those who bound the floating pieces of wreckage and capsized boats together into a makeshift raft, by which many were saved. The other singers who managed to keep near him and help build the raft were G. B. Lane. Risca Williams, Gwyn Jones, Spencer Hill and Preston Smith." www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily...

the "ballyhoo artist" is the fellow in the Charlie Chaplin outift balancing his cane on his hat, presumably to attract customers to the Chaplin movies being shown there that day. A commentator on a forum devoted to Coney Island has described the film on the banners, including the release dates, all from March or April, 1915. www.coneyisland.com/cgi-bin/yabb/YaBB.pl?num=1247857344 Another notes that the ticket guy at the far right of the picture is selling tickets to Feucht's Drop-the-Dip roller coaster on the south side of the Bowery at about 15th.

Not Surf Avenue, but Bowery. The large brick building in the distance on the left hand side of the street is Henderson's Musical Theater. The photographer in the linked picture is standing up against Henderson's, looking in the same direction, and the marquee shows the same acts in both photos. The scene today, per Google Maps, is comparitively grim: maps.google.com/maps?q=coney+island+bowery+map&ll=40....
The money is not in restaurants or vending or attractions - its in selling straw hats!

This is Coney Island, but not Surf Avenue, which was (and is) much wider and had streetcar tracks. This is taken a block away, on Bowery, looking eastward, as this New York Historical Society photo from 1923 makes clear. digitalmetro.cdmhost.com/cdm/singleitem/collection/p16124... (the 'fit to window' button is the easiest way to see the picture) On the right of the NYHS photo, you see the metal stairs in the left foreground of LOC's photo, and the thing in the middle of the intersection.. a water fountain? Henderson's Music Hall was a Coney Island institution. In the LOC's photo, we see the electric sign at upper left with the top part of "Henderson's" cut off and the vaudeville acts listed below. Princess Radjah was a faux-Egyptian with a snake act based on Cleopatra's suicide by asp, only with a much bigger snake. The other acts were well known in their day on the Keith circuit, which ran Henderson's. You can also see the Brooklyn House on the other photo. Henderson's was demolished in 2010, the sad story here: amusingthezillion.com/2010/08/19/thors-coney-island-crack...

From doglawreporter.blogspot.com/2011/06/messenger-dogs-soldie... "Edwin H. Richardson Lieutenant Colonel Edwin H. Richardson was not a shy man and portrays himself as fighting for years against institutional ignorance about the value of war dogs. Even before the war, he states that “I was the sole person who took any interest in trained dogs for the army and police, and the outflow from my kennels constituted the only source of supply.“ When World War I began, Richardson tried to persuade the powers that be to let him train sentry dogs, already known to be in use by the Germans. His idea having been rejected, he began training ambulance dogs, but this came to little because the Germans did not respect “the inviolability of the sacred symbol of the Red Cross, whether on man or beast, hospital or ship.” Also, the nature of the Great War was that it involved little movement, often only glacial change in the positions of the front lines, which did not suit ambulance dogs that could be used primarily in finding the wounded after a battlefield was controlled. Richardson concedes that the “only ambulance dogs that were used with any success were those with the German army when the Russians were retreating on the Eastern front.” Richardson, Edwin Hautonville, 1863- wrote "British war dogs, their training and psychology" [1920], archive.org/details/britishwardogsth00richrich Elsewhere his middle name is spelled "Hautenville" and the title page of "Forty Years with Dogs" (found somewhere on eBay) has that spelling. See also community-2.webtv.net/Hahn-50thAP-K9/K9History13/ A BIOGRAPHY OF E. H. RICHARDSON

Cool find, Artolog! The actress headlining on the posters (both sides of the doorway) is Beulah Poynter (1886-1960). She was from St. Louis, which would explain her popularity in that city. Here's her IMDB page: www.imdb.com/name/nm0694718/ But there's no film listed there from before 1914. The New York Public Library has a lot of images of Beulah Poynter (she was on Broadway as well as in films): digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchresult.cfm... Title of the flim looks to be "Little Lord Fauntleroy." The earliest film version of that seems to also be 1914.

thanks.. I was surprised to find no wikipedia (or other internet) full biographical sketch of Poynter, as she was clearly a top actress of the era, both on stage and later screen.  She also wrote many plays, screenplays for films, and even had a spin as a pulp fiction novelist later in her career.  I imagine her life story is very interesting.  This image is dated 1910.  I guess the theater was still putting on legitimate theater or vaudeville at that point, so it was probably a stage production.  Poynter was born in Missouri and would have been 24 in 1910.

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breaker_boy "A breaker boy was a coal-mining worker in the United States and United Kingdom whose job was to separate impurities from coal by hand in a coal breaker. Although breaker boys were primarily children, elderly coal miners who could no longer work in the mines because of age, disease, or accident were also sometimes employed as breaker boys. The use of breaker boys began in the mid-1860s. Although public disapproval of the employment of children as breaker boys existed by the mid-1880s, the practice did not end until the 1920s."

This photo appears to be taken on the occasion of the award of the first Franklin Medals to Edison and Dutch scientist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes at a ceremony n Philadelphia on May 19, 1915. A newspaper account in the Franklin Insitute archives mentions that Onnes' medal would be received by the Dutch Minister, Chevalier van Rappard, who sits to the right of Mrs. Edison and holds a scroll and medal box. [Heike Kamerlingh Onnes, of Leiden, Holland, ... received a Franklin Medal ..., "in recognition of his long-continued and indefatigable labors in low-temperature research which have enriched physical science not only with a great number of new methods and ingenious devices, but also with achievements and discoveries of the first magnitude."] www.fi.edu/learn/case-files/edison/reward.html The others are either officers of the Franklin Institute, or pioneers and luminaries in electricity and related fields invited to speak or be present at the ceremony. Thomas Edison and his second wife, Mina Miller Edison, at front right. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_edison Top left, electrical engineer R. B. Owens known for his work with fellow McGill University professor and 1908 Nobel laureate Ernest Rutherford with Thorium (Radon). www.icds2011.com/rutherford.shtml He was Secretary of the Franklin Institute in 1915. www.fi.edu/learn/case-files/edison/full/busy.jpg Top row, third from left, Frank J. Sprague, inventor of electrical products and systems. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_J._Sprague Top right, "Robert Tait McKenzie (May 26, 1867 – April 28, 1938) was an internationally renowned Canadian-born sculptor, doctor, soldier, physical educator, athlete and Scouter," McKenzie designed the Franklin Medal www.fi.edu/learn/case-files/edison/full/article.jpg en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R._Tait_McKenzie Second from right, William Stanley, 1858-1916, inventor of the first transformer and many other innovative electrical products. books.google.com/books?id=Te85AQAAIAAJ&lpg=PA119&... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Stanley,_Jr. Front left, Samuel Insull (November 11, 1859 – July 16, 1938) was a British-born American business magnate, who founded the company which became General Electric. He greatly contributed to creating an integrated electrical infrastructure in the United States. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insull,_Samuel He also backed the creation of the Franklin Medal. Left of Edison, Dr Walton Clark, president of the Franklin Institute from 1907-1924. old.library.temple.edu/collections/urbana/clark-777.jsp;j... Left rear, John J. Carty, president AT&T, according to the newspaper article cited above, Chief Engineer according to Wikipedia, and president of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers from 1915 to 1916. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_J._Carty en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_J._Carty

Stromboli was a chestnut gelding foaled in 1911, by Fair Play (sire of Man O' War) out of St. Priscilla. He won over 60 races between 1913 & 1918, including numerous major New York stakes races, for owner/breeder August Belmont Sr: www.tbhorsepedigree.com/library/horse/Stromboli.php The jockey was Clarence Turner (1893 - 1957): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Turner_%28jockey%29 If this photo was taken the same day as others in this set, this would be right after their win in the 1915 Metropolitan Handicap, a race that is still a fixure at Belmont each May. For their efforts, they took home a winner's purse of $2,325; By contrast, the horse that won this year's Metropolitan Handicap was awarded $450,000. Chart for the race can be found here (scroll to race 4): kdl.kyvl.org/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=drf1910s;cc=drf1...

From the look of him and the company he's keeping, "A.A. Gallatin" is probably Albert Eugene Gallatin (1881-1952), who inherited the vast fortune developed by his great-grandfather Albert Gallatin (early American Secretary of the Treasury and friend of the first John Jacob Astor), and was one of the most eligible socialite bachelors in New York of his era (excepting the pictured Mrs. J.J. Clara von Ende married New York brewery executive Henry L. Liebmann; they had three children. Clara started a school of music on the East Side teaching poor children for ten cents a lesson; here's a 1905 letter describing her program: cdm128401.cdmhost.com/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p1505... In 1914, Clara sued Henry for a separation, on the basis of cruelty (she said that he beat her often, beginning on their honeymoon; their eldest son, Joseph, confirmed that he heard frequent mistreatment); he countersued for divorce, and named eight men in his suit. By August 1915, a Nevada divorce had been granted, and Henry had remarried to a young woman named Ida Teichman.

This photograph must date to ~29th April 1915.  The Times has a piece on Haldane's report on the nature and cause of the injuries to soldiers which he had presented to the authorities two days before.  Having no other means of protecting soldiers from gas at the time an appeal went out to the women of the country to make gauze masks in the hope that they would give some protection.

So, b0b42, there was no supplier's firm to have a Baroness at that point only the desire of the women of Great Britain to do what they could for our troops.
