Robert Marsden Shaw was a New York banker whose wife, Katherine Lyall Shaw, left him for another man, Richard S. Darling. In 1915 Shaw sued Darling for alienation of affection and had him prosecuted under the Mann Act for transporting Mrs. Shaw across state lines for immoral purposes. Darling was aquitted in the Mann Act prosecution and Shaw dropped the alienation of affection suit. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C15F9395C13738... Shaw and his wife must have divorced, because in June 1916 he married another woman, Lillian Mahoney. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E12F93A5B17738... There's a close up of Shaw on the LOC Photo division site www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005018715/ that hasn't been loaded on Flickr yet.
There are a number of these floor-level shots of trial proceedings. I wonder if the photographer shot this surreptitiously or if the judge permitted pictures if the camera wasn't raised?
I was wondering the same thing. This one in particular really looks like the photographer was trying to hide the camera.

Thanks for connecting up the two photographs and the information about Shaw and the trial. We can add some information when we next update the description. Good question about photography during trial proceedings. I don't know the precise answer, although Emma Little, who published an article about Bain many years ago had a colorful account of how one of the office boys Bain trained to take pictures got the first photos of a trial in a New York federal court, where photographers were banned on pain of contempt of court. The boy "got a step-ladder and placed it in front of the court-room door, put his camera through the high transom and let the flash light, leaped down and dashed off with his camera, leaving the step-ladder to block the door." (Emma Little, "The Father of News Photography: George Grantham Bain," Picturescope 20 (1972): 203.) A talent for being surreptitious from any angle may have been the order of the day!

On March 17, 1915, the 15,000 ton superdreadnaught USS Pensylvania was launched at the Newport News (Virginia) Shipbuilding Drydock Company. It was the largest battleship ever launched anywhere in the world, Miss Elizabeth Ludoff Kolb (1896-1979) of Germantown, Pennsylvania, daughter of Louis J. Kolb of Philadelphia and a senior at National Park Seminary in Forest Glen, Maryland, had been invited to the launching ceremonies by Pennsylvania Governor Brumbaugh (term 1915-1919), who called her "the most beautiful and sweetest girl in Pennsylvania". Elizabeth was the official "sponsor" of the ship, which, as far as I can tell, means she offered the name for the ship. Nineteen years young, Elizabeth arrived with her maids of honor, fellow classmates Miss Katherine Kolb (1900–1979) (who was also her younger sister), Miss Katherine Martin and Miss Mildred Harold. Following the prayer and with the words "I Christen thee Pennsylvania", Miss Kolb broke a bottle of champagne on the bow and set in motion one of the greatest battleships of all time.
Before the launch:

Kolb of Philadelphia and a senior at National Park Seminary in Forest Glen, Maryland, had been invited to the launching ceremonies by Pennsylvania Governor Brumbaugh (term 1915-1919), who called her "the most beautiful and sweetest girl in Pennsylvania". Elizabeth was the official "sponsor" of the ship, which, as far as I can tell, means she offered the name for the ship. Nineteen years young, Elizabeth arrived with her maids of honor, fellow classmates Miss Katherine Kolb (1900–1979) (who was also her younger sister), Miss Katherine Martin and Miss Mildred Harold. Following the prayer and with the words "I Christen thee Pennsylvania", Miss Kolb broke a bottle of champagne on the bow and set in motion one of the greatest battleships of all time.

"Admiral Sir Edmund Samuel Poe, R.N., was born on 11 September 1849. Educated at the Royal Naval Academy, Gosport, he entered the Royal Navy in 1862. He served on the Bombay when destroyed by fire off Montevideo, 1854, and on the Newcastle where he won the R.H.S. Medal and clasp. He was appointed Naval Advisor to the Inspector-General of Fortifications, 1889-90 and was in command of the Training Squadron as Commodore 2nd Class, 1897-1900. He was second in command of the Home Fleet, 1903; in command of the 1st Cruiser Squadron, 1904-05; Commander-in Chief, East Indies, 1905-07; Cape of Good Hope, 1907-08. Appointed A.D.C. [Naval Aide-de-Camp] to the Queen, 1899 and to the King, 1901; he was First and Principal A.D.C. to the King, 1912-14. He retired from the Navy as an Admiral in September 1914. During his career he had been honoured with the G.C.V.O. in 1912 and K.C.B. in 1908, together with awards from France, Japan and Turkey. Admiral Sir Edmund Poe died on 1 April 1921." www.dnw.co.uk/medals/auctionarchive/viewspecialcollection... See also: www.dreadnoughtproject.org/tfs/index.php/Edmund_Samuel_Po... The ship has an interesting story. A german passenger liner, converted at the German naval base in Tsingtao to an armed auxiliary cruiser, made 11 "kills" of Allied ships. Then she surrendered in March, 1915 to the then-neutral U.S. When America entered the war, she was seized and converted to a U.S. Navy ship, the U.S.S. De Kalb. More at: navalwarfare.blogspot.com/2012/04/german-auxiliary-cruise...

I can't find anything on these two women. There was a jitney bus (i.e., shared-ride, independent, unorganized 5 cent public transportation) craze in America in 1914 and 1915. The March 30, 1915 New York Times ran a long story on the phenomenon, noting there were at least some female entepreneurs involved. At that point, there were not jitneys in New York City, but the article said they were "at our gates." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B12F73F5D1A728... Typo in caption, Angel s/b Angle. Mrs. Helen M. Angle was on trial in March, 1915, for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, Connecticut in June, 1914. Helen was divorced from her husband of twelve years, Frank W. Angle. Her father was Leonard Blondell, a wealthy former Stamford Councilman who was retired from the coal and road contracting business Waldo Ballou was was a friend of her fathers, and a leading Republican politician and Stamford business man. Helen met Waldo in 1911 after his wife died. Waldo proposed to Helen several times, but she said he was too old. He was 69, she was 40. Mrs Angle took the stand in her own defense, and told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Judge William H. Williams presided. Eight months after the trial, Helen remarried her former husband, Frank Angle, a foreman at Union Metallic Cartridge Company in Stamford. It was said that during her trial Mr Angle's sympathies were aroused, and he was a frequent visitor in the court. [1] [2] [3]

William H. Brennan (1865-1923), Chief of Police, Stamford, Connecticut, testified for the prosecution in the manslaughter trial of Mrs. Helen M. Angle in March, 1915. She was charged with causing the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in 1914. "Helen" and (Chief) "Bill" were on a first-name basis before the alleged murder, as she was the daughter of a former Stamford city councilman. William Brennan was appointed Chief in 1905 by then Mayor Homer S. Cummings. Cummings led the prosecution of Helen Angle as State's Attorney for Fairfield County. Waldo Ballou, the victim, was was a friend of Helen's father, and a leading Republican politician and Stamford business man. Waldo had served on the Stamford Police Committee from 1901-1904, and was appointed by the Stamford City Council. [1] [2] For more details of the trial see the Bain/LOC photo of Mrs. Helen Angle on Flickr. Note: For caption clarity ;-)  William Brennan was the Chief of Police in Stamford, (S't'm'f'd ?) Connecticut, where the victim died, and Helen Angle lived. The trial took place in the Superior Court of neighboring Bridgeport, Connecticut, which is the county seat, and is likely where this photo was taken -- and why "Bridgeport' (well, "B'd'g'p't") is in the caption.

Defense attorneys in Stamford, CT manslaughter trial of Helen Angle, for the killing of her friend Waldo Ballou, which began March 3, 1915. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C03E5DB1238E633A... See notes under:

Jacob B. Klein (1862-1932) of Bridgeport, Nicholas C. Downs (1862-1920) and former Probate Judge H. Stanley Finch (1852-1942) (not pictured), were three of the best known criminal lawyers in Connecticut. They were retained by Mrs. Angle's father, Mr. Leonard Blondel, to defend his daughter in her March, 1915, trial for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, Connecticut in June, 1914. Nicholas C. Downs, former Judge of the Stamford City Court, was the chief defense counsel. Helen was divorced from her husband of twelve years, Frank W. Angle. Her father was Leonard Blondel, a wealthy former Stamford Councilman who was retired from the coal and road contracting business Waldo Ballou was was a friend of her fathers, and a leading Republican politician and Stamford business man. Helen met Waldo in 1911 after his wife died. Waldo proposed to Helen several times, but she said he was too old. He was 69, she was 40. Chief Counsel Downs put the defendant, Mrs. Angle on the stand to testify in her own defense. Under direct examination she told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Judge William H. Williams presided. Chief Counsel Downs was happy with the verdict and said:
"I regard the verdict as correct ... I dare say the same verdict would have been reached without Mrs. Angle going on the stand, but as one member of the jury said, ' It was a good thing to let her vindicate herself.' "
Eight months after the trial, Helen remarried her former husband, Frank Angle, a foreman at Union Metallic Cartridge Company in Stamford. It was said that during her trial Mr Angle's sympathies were aroused, and he was a frequent visitor in the court. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8]

Probably Howard Barnum, gatekeeper at Matteawan State Hospital who was accused of taking a bribe to let Harry Thaw escape select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C1EFF395B1373...

Judge William Henry Williams (b.1850) presided.over the twelve day jury trial of Mrs. Helen M. Angle in March, 1915, for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, (Fairfield County) Connecticut in June, 1914. The trial was held in the Superior Court at Bridgeport, Connecticut, the county seat of Fairfield County. The all male jury had an average age of fifty, the youngest was thirty five. The question before the jury was, did Waldo Ballou, Helen Angle's elderly suitor, fall down the stairs from Helen's apartment, after calling on her late one night, fracturing his skull... or was he, as the State contends, pushed -- or hit over the head with an iron? Judge Williams twice warned the lawyers and press against untimely disclosure or discussions of the evidence to be introduced. He said that under Connecticut law any one making public testimony in advance of its introduction in court would be open to a charge of contempt. Mrs Angle took the stand in her own defense, and told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Prior to his appointment to the bench, Judge William H. Williams was State's Attorney for New Haven County, and a partner in the firm of Wooster, Williams & Gager.  [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
Thanks Pixel Wrangler, We'll add his full name to our record.

Judge William Henry Williams (b.1850) presided.over the twelve day jury trial of Mrs. Helen M. Angle in March, 1915, for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, (Fairfield County) Connecticut in June, 1914. The trial was held in the Superior Court at Bridgeport, Connecticut, the county seat of Fairfield County. The all male jury had an average age of fifty, the youngest was thirty five. The question before the jury was, did Waldo Ballou, Helen Angle's elderly suitor, fall down the stairs from Helen's apartment, after calling on her late one night, fracturing his skull... or was he, as the State contends, pushed -- or hit over the head with an iron? Judge Williams twice warned the lawyers and press against untimely disclosure or discussions of the evidence to be introduced. He said that under Connecticut law any one making public testimony in advance of its introduction in court would be open to a charge of contempt. Mrs Angle took the stand in her own defense, and told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Prior to his appointment to the bench, Judge William H. Williams was State's Attorney for New Haven County, and a partner in the firm of Wooster, Williams & Gager.  [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]

Connecticut State Attorney Homer Stille Cummings (1870-1956) prosecuted Mrs. Helen M. Angle in her March, 1915, trial for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, Connecticut in June, 1914. Cummings was assisted at trial by Albert Phillips of Stamford, former secretary of state for Connecticut (1913-1915). Homer Cummings was appointed State's Attorney for Fairfield County, Connecticut, on July 1, 1914, and his first official act was to take up the inquiry into the death of Waldo Ballou. Cummings served as State's Attorney for ten years from 1914 to 1924. The Government did not prevail in its case against Helen Angle. For more details of the Helen Angle trial see the Bain/LOC photo of Mrs. Helen Angle on Flickr.   In 1893, Cummings graduated from Yale Law School in New Haven. He was elected mayor of Stamford, Connecticut three times from 1900-1906. As mayor, in 1905, Cummings appointed William H. Brennan as Chief of Police for Stamford. Brennan would later investigate the case against Helen Angle and testify against her. Homer Cummings founded the legal firm of Cummings & Lockwood in 1909. He later served as chairman of the Democratic National Committee between 1919 and 1920. He went on to serve as United States Attorney General for Franklin Roosevelt from 1933 to 1939. "In 1947 Hollywood made a motion picture called "Boomerang" about Cumming's early career as a prosecutor in Connecticut. This was a sensational murder case that also included a dramatic courtroom scene where Cummings had a live gun aimed at his head at a certain angle and fired. This was to show that the gun could indeed fire but not at the angle a witness said it was used. In this trial Cummings also turned around to prove the man he was prosecuting was innocent after he found evidence to that effect. "Boomerang" became a landmark motion picture for its fully dramatic but documentary style where Cummings real name was not announced till the end of the film which starred Dana Andrews as Cummings"  [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7]   There is another Bain/LOC photograph of Homer S. Cummings here:

Mrs. Helen M. Angle was on trial in March, 1915, for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, Connecticut on June 23, 1914. Helen was divorced from her husband of twelve years, Frank W. Angle. Her father was Leonard Blondel, a wealthy former Stamford Councilman who was retired from the coal and road contracting business Waldo Ballou was was a friend of her fathers, and a leading Republican politician and Stamford business man. Helen met Waldo in 1911 after his wife died. Waldo proposed to Helen several times, but she said he was too old. He was 69, she was 40. Mrs Angle took the stand in her own defense, and told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Judge William H. Williams presided. Eight months after the trial, Helen remarried her former husband, Frank Angle, a foreman at Union Metallic Cartridge Company in Stamford. It was said that during her trial Mr Angle's sympathies were aroused, and he was a frequent visitor in the court. [1] [2] [3]

Mrs. Helen M. Angle was on trial in March, 1915, for manslaughter in the death of her friend Waldo R. Ballou in Stamford, Connecticut in June, 1914. Helen was divorced from her husband of twelve years, Frank W. Angle (b.1869). Her father was Leonard Blondel, a wealthy former Stamford Councilman who was retired from the coal and road contracting business. After her arrest, her father said, "I will not discuss my daughter's case at all except to say she has convinced me of her absolute innocence. And I will spend every cent I have and give all of my energies to proving her innocence." Waldo Ballou was was a friend of her fathers, and a leading Republican politician and Stamford business man. He served on the Stamford Police Committee from 1901-1904 -- appointed by the Stamford City Council. Helen met Waldo in 1911 after his wife died. Waldo proposed to Helen several times, but she said he was too old. He was 69, she was 40. Mrs Angle took the stand in her own defense, and told her version of what happened on the night of June 23, 1914. More than 500 people were turned away from the packed courtroom. After a twelve day trial the jury deliberated for one hour and forty-five minutes before returning a verdict of not guilty, after three ballots. Judge William H. Williams presided. Eight months after the trial, Helen remarried her former husband, Frank Angle, a foreman at Union Metallic Cartridge Company in Stamford. It was said that during her trial Mr Angle's sympathies were aroused, and he was a frequent visitor in the court. Oscar Lewisohn was married to actress Edna May (1878-1948, born Edna May Pettie); here's a portrait of her done in 1915: www.jssgallery.org/Other_Artists/William_Orpen/Mrs_Oscar_...

Oscar was in the news quite a bit. He inherited a fortune from his father, who was in the copper business, and spent almost all of it before he died at the age of 34. He was fond of horses and motor sports, getting a very early speeding ticket for $125 in 1907. He was erroneously reported dead in a car crash in 1909. When he died for real in 1917, his estate was reportedly worth $6 million, but on appraisal was found to be less than a tenth that amount. I've been unable to find news of the couple's arrival in NYC, which apparently happened in 1915. Maybe they sailed in to a different port and went overland. Edna sailed back to England on the White Star liner Baltic in December 1918.

HMS Agamemnon was one of two Lord Nelson-class pre-dreadnought battleships launched in 1906 and completed in 1908. She was the Royal Navy's second-to-last pre-dreadnought battleship to be built, followed by her sister ship, Lord Nelson. She survived the Dardanelles campaign and was the last pre-dreadnought in existence when she was scrapped in 1927 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Agamemnon_(1906)

It's often said that "First Reports From a War Zone Are Always Wrong". Here's a headline from a front-page New York Times story of June 15, 1915:         ANOTHER BRITISH         BATTLESHIP SUNK;   The Agamemnon, 16,500 Tons, Went Down in Dardanelles in May.   THE SHIP WAS TORPEDOED  All the Officers and Crew Said   to Have Been Saved -- News     Suppressed in England.   The article states, "A wireless message from Berlin announcing the loss of the Agamemnon was picked up in London, but the censors would not permit its publication or transmission over the cables." Remarkably, The Times goes on to boast how they were able to get confirmation of the sinking through their "word of mouth" sources that "circulate within a limited circle" of people. The article is an interesting glimpse at the forces of possible propaganda, rumor, gossip, fear and censorship involving one country at war (England) and the U.S. which, while not yet in the war, certainly regarded it as their number-one concern.
This is the bridge that Werner Horn tried to blow up in 1915. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Werner_Horn

The Spy Who Came In From The Cold Werner Van Horn, an alleged German army reservist, arrived by train in Vanceboro, Maine (population 147 at the 2000 census) on a Saturday night from New York, and put up at a local hotel. He had intended to escape into Canada after blowing up the international railroad bridge the following night, but the February night was so cold (28° below zero F) (–33° C) that one of his hands and one foot were badly frozen, and his clothing was encrusted with ice. So he went back to the hotel in Vanceboro, He was arrested the following morning at 7:00am by a Deputy sheriff and a Maine Central Railroad officer. It seems the German was the only stranger in Vanceboro. — The New York Times
Also see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanceboro_international_bridge_bombing The bridge appears to have been replaced. See www.railpictures.net/viewphoto.php?id=298717&nseq=5

In February 1915, the Duke of Portland was in the news query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9502E3DC1238E633A... "LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The Duke of Portland, who for thirty years has been one of the leading figures on the English turf, has caused to be canceled all his racing entries for the Epsom track, including those for the 1915 and 1916 Derby, because of the refusal of the Epsom Association to do without the use of its clubhouse for a few days. " The clubhouse was being used as a military hospital and the Duke reckoned that racegoers should be able to do without a clubhouse in the circumstances. also query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A00E2DC1238E633A... "ENGLISH DERBY OFF.; Duke of Portland Cancels All Ascot Races for Two Years. LONDON, Eng., Feb. 25. -- There will be no races at the historic Epsom track for the next two years, as the result of the Duke of Portland canceling all the fixtures of the turf that were down for contest during 1915 and 1916. This means that among other big features the classic Derby will not be raced during that period."

Anna Pavlova (Pavlovna) (1881 ?-1931) was a Russian ballerina. She joined the Imperial Ballet in 1899 and became a prima ballerina in 1906. Her American debut was made with Mikhail Mordkin, on March 1, 1910, at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York City, in a revival of Delibes's ballet, Coppelia. After the debut a New York critic declared such dancing had not been seen on the local stage during the present generation and praised the supreme ease with which Pavlova executed the most difficult tricks of the dancer's art. After 1913, she danced independently with her own company around the world. Some of her more famous dances include The Dragon fly, Californian Poppy, and Gavotte. "Pavlova is perhaps most renowned for creating the role of "The Dying Swan", a solo choreographed for her by Michel Fokine. The ballet, created in 1905, is danced to Le cygne from The Carnival of the Animals by Camille Saint-Saëns." Pavlova was married to her accompanist, Victor d'Andre. The marriage was announced by the dancer during her last American tour in 1924-25, which was said to be her farewell appearance in this country. Commenting on her marriage at that time, the dancer said:
"For an artist there is no husband. Pavlova the artist and Pavlova the wife, they are two very different persons, so I keep them separate. My dancing belongs to the world, but my husband to myself."
Anna died at the age of 45 of pleurisy at the height of her fame in 1931. She is considered one of the finest classical ballet dancers in history. [1] [2] [3] [4]
I like how casual she appears. You don't see that in many of these old pictures.

In February 1915, she was dancing in New York, at the Century, with the Ballet Russe. See ad highlighting PAVLOWA at lower left of chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-02-15/ed-...
if she was born 1881 and died 1931, how could she die at age 45?

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/70875173@N00] gov_calif – Thanks for (as they say) "doing the math" ;) The birth date of 1881 came from the Wikipedia reference (#2 above), while the "died at ... age 45" came from The New York Times reference (#3 above). The Times, in that January 23, 1931, article listed her date of birth as Jan. 31, 1885. Several other U.S. papers reporting on her death gave the same information. A further look into Anna's date of birth produces inconclusive results. In addition to differences in the year, there are differences between the month and day as a result of Old Style (O.S.) and New Style (N.S.) dates: February 12 [O.S. January 31]. A Times book review of 'Margot Fonteyn': Leaping Beauty, gives Anna's birth year as 1882. A Times movie review of the 1984 movie, "Pavlova -- A Woman For All Time", lists her birth as "1882?". Classical Ballet News mentions both the January 31st and February 12th dates, and gives the year as 1881, commenting that she died "a few days shy of her 50th birthday". Google's search results summary is "Best guess for Anna Pavlova Date of birth is February 12, 1881 -- Mentioned on at least 4 websites including wikipedia org, imdb com and topsynergy com " For their part, this past February, Google celebrated Anna's 131st birthday on February 12, 2012, with a Google Doodle:
In an article entitled "Anna Pavlova: Ballerina Absoluta", originally published in The Ave Maria, Malana Mercurio wrote:
"Anna Pavlova was born in St. Petersburg, premature and frail, sometime in the early 1880s. The exact year is not certain and if Anna herself knew, she never told anyone. She was the only child of poor parents and had the misfortune to lose her father, reputed to have been shiftless, when she was two."
"Born sometime in the early 1880s" sounds good to me -- and perhaps someone else will have more information. In the meantime I have redacted the reference to her age ("died at ... age 45") from the comment above, and changed the birth date to "?".

"For an artist there is no husband. Pavlova the artist and Pavlova the wife, they are two very different persons, so I keep them separate. My dancing belongs to the world, but my husband to myself."
Anna died of pleurisy at the height of her fame in 1931. She is considered one of the finest classical ballet dancers in history. [1] [2] [3] [4]

Passow was the captain of the St. Paul. H.A.C. is probably Honourable Artillery Company. From what I can see "Fargo Camp" may have been on Salisbury Plain and not in Aldershot. However, it may just have been a summer exercise,

More on this: "From 1899, part of Salisbury Plain to the north west of the village was used for artillery practice and a camp was set up on Durrington Down. By the beginning of the First World War there were three tented camps known as Durrington, Larkhill, and Fargo Camps; which were later replaced by permanent brick buildings. The military expansion caused a decline in all types of farming as the army occupied most of the land, however, the rapid rise in population brought about the establishment of many shops and business. After the Second World War the town expanded between Netheravon Road and the river Avon, including large council estates and two new schools. Durrington remains as an army-orientated community." www.wiltshire.gov.uk/south_wiltshire_settlement_setting_a...
Well turned out for a practice.

"The changing epoch began in 1898 when much of the parish was acquired by the army. From 1899 the part of Salisbury Plain to the north west of the village was used for artillery practice and a camp was set up on Durrington Down. By the beginning of the First World War there were three tented camps known as Durrington, Larkhill, and Fargo Camps. In 1914 the Larkhill light military railway was built from Ratfyn in Amesbury to Fargo Camp and a large military hospital was built at that camp. During the war the tents at Larkhill Camp were replaced by huts and in 1916 the Stonehenge Inn was rebuilt by the Portsmouth United Brewery, who had acquired it. The war memorial was built on the base of the ancient cross. From 1920 Larkhill Camp became the headquarters of the School of Artillery and permanent brick building were put up." history.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getcom.php?id=84

James Paul Clarke (1854-1916) was a United States Senator and the 18th Governor of Arkansas. He was born in Mississippi and graduated from the law department of the University of Virginia. He then practiced law in Helena, Arkansas. He married Miss Frances M. Moore of Helena in 1883. J.P. Clarke served the state of Arkansas as a member of the State house of representatives 1886-1888; member of the State senate 1888-1892, attorney general of Arkansas 1892-1894; and as Governor of Arkansas 1895-1896; Clarke, a/k/a "Old Cotton Top", was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1903, and served as President pro tempore of the Senate from 1913 to 1916. Last re-elected in November, 1914, he served the Senate for thirteen years until his death in 1916.  [1] [2] [3] For several years Senator Clarke was Chairman of the Committee on Commerce, and he was the ranking Democratic member of the Foreign Relations Committee. Senator Clarke was also the Chairman of the Committee on Disposition of Useless Executive Papers (1909-1913).

The 19th Alabama Infantry Regiment first fought in the Battle of Shiloh, April 6 - 7, 1862.  It lost one-third of its men during this bloody, two-day battle.  The 19th Alabama had 219 men killed or wounded during the fighting at Shiloh.  Private Paris' Company "I" was predominantly from Cherokee County, Alabama.  This year marks the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Shiloh.

Major Thomas B. Beall.   His brother was Major James Franklin Beall (b.1837) of the 21st Reg't, NC Infantry. Both men studied medicine at the Universities of North Carolina and Virginia. (The reference is not clear – the brother he studied medicine with may have been "Robert".) James Beall gave a first-hand account of one of battles he participated in with his brother, Thomas, at Fishers' Hill, Virginia:      "During this battle, occurred one of the most trying ordeals of the writer's life. We were moving on the enemy, when the writer met his brother, Capt. T.B. Beall, of the 14th NC Regiment, coming out desperately wounded through the lung, the blood spurting from his breast. There wasn't time to give him a word of sympathy, much less attention, leaving him as I then thought for the last time in this world. He had the good fortuen [sic] soon after, to meet with an ambulance, which took him and the gallant Lt. W.G. Foy, of the 21st NC Reg't, who was also deperately [sic] wounded, to the field hospital. They received immediate attention, and both finally recovered, but were left more or less disabled for life." [1]

1stcorichmondhowitzers.com/men has a picture of William Savage Moore (similar enough to be the same person) and the following info: MOORE, William Savage: Henrico Co.; age 16; enl. Capt. W. W. Parker's Co. Va. Light Arty. Dischd. for disability 12/10/62. Enl. 1864(?); Pvt., 1st Co. Transf. 3/21/65, to Co. I, 15th Regt. Va. Nil., Capt. Prison records carry him with the rank of 2nd Lt. and Capt., and indicate he was wded. in left arm, and captured 4/3/65, and sent to U.S. hosp., Washington, D.C. Released 6/6/65, age 19. ranger95.com/civil_war/virginia/artillery/rosters/parkers... has additional info: MOORE, WILLIAM SAVAGE - Private. March 14, 1862. Age is given as 18 on muster roll, but Moore was really only 15 or 16 at enlistment. Present-MR #1-2. Discharged by surgeon for disability after his mother had applied for that judgment. The surgeon found nothing to justify a disability discharge other than the mother's unsupported statement that young Moore was subject to frequent attacks of Diarrhea and her claim that "he is in Every respect unfit to do Military duty." The surgeon denied this claim, but did find evidence that the boy was only 16 that May and had enlisted without his mother's consent. There was also some difficulty with papers signed by a long-missing husband. (S.O. 289, 12/10/62, AIGO and S.O. 242, 10/16/62, AIGO). There is a note in VSL which says Moore transferred to "1st Howitzer 1863." This is borne out by the listing of "W. S. Moore" in the roster of the First Company, Richmond Howitzers. Interestingly, the same page has: MOORE, JOHN C. - Private. March 14, 1862. Age is listed as 18 on the mustering document, but Moore was actually 16 in May, 1862. Present-MR #1-2. Discharged by a surgeon for disability, Oct. 8, 1862, although in effect the discharge was for being under age, and enlisting without parental consent. (S.O. 236, AIGO). Note the almost precisely parallel case of William Savage Moore. The two Moores were quite surely related, possibly even twins, although CSR gives no indications along that line.

That's supposed to be an H, not an A. C.H. Canby was a trade broker, head of CH Canby & Co., a member of the Chicago Board of Trade and its president c.1913-14. He testified before a number of congressional committees and his name appeared with some regularity in the press regarding wartime trade, grain shortages, etc; the papers did occasionally type C.A. (e.g. at the end of this NYT article from '21), but they seemed to get it right most of the time (e.g. in the NYT in '15). The following appears in the Thursday, March 15, 1923, Janesville [Wisconsin] Daily Gazette
Retired Broker Dies Chicaco — Caleb Harlan Canby, Sr., 67, retired broker and former president of the Chicago Board of Trade died here Wednesday night from pneumonia.
Unfortunately I haven't found any photos of Mr Canby, so I can't say for certain. But given the dearth of info that comes up for "C.A. Canby", and the fact that the photo before this is of another Chicago grain merchant, C.H. seems like a safe bet.

"The Kansas Senate today has a woman Sergeant-at-Arms for the first time in its history. She Is Miss Effie Loader.  Lieutenant Governor W. Y. (William Yoast) Morgan appointed her In recognition of his women constituents." — The Washington [DC] Herald,  January 17, 1915.

Eagle Rock -Northeast Los Angeles News Boulevard Sentinel VOLUME XIII ISSUE 3 News and Views for Northeast Los Angeles July 2009 Looking Back by Joe Walker 80 years ago this month- Eagle Rock A social gathering was organized by the local women's clubs in what was called the "Argus Bowl" and "Argus Gardens" on July 7, 1929, when a Russian musical troupe entertained the local ladies. Dr. Sonia Poushkareff claimed to be related to Russian nobility as she regaled the group with the story of her life and entertained the audience with music from her 25 piece orchestra. Poushkareff stayed active in local affairs for many years after that, alternating from appearing at social functions to taking anti-Soviet/anti-Communist stands. She made a living as a dentist after arriving in the U.S. in 1924, and carried several scars from bullet wounds she suffered in the Russian Revolution.

This photo is from 1927 apparently, therefore out of place chronologically in the general flow of the news photos. I think Flyvapnet has correctly identified the subject. This looks like a publicity photo from a movie or play. There is a small article on Sonia Poushkareff in the Brooklyn Daily Star of October 11, 1927 that recounts her perilous experiences in the Russian Civil War and her emigration to the U.S., where she studied dentistry and began acting and writing screenplays. The article states she is currently appearing in a film adaptation of Tolstoy's "Resurrection" at the Loew's Astoria, which was released in March, 1927. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2015/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20... There are 1929 and 1930 petitions for U.S. Citizenship (behind the paywall at fold3.com) for a Sophia Georgievna Poushkareff, occupation dentist, born in Russia in 1893. It recites that she arrived in New York in 1923, and had lived in Los Angeles since1926. The petition requests that her first name be changed to Sonia. There are numerous references to her in the Los Angeles Times in the 20's and 30's. She seems to have put on frequent pageants and Russian cultural events. She apparently sometimes referred to herself as Countess and Princess. There is a reference to her in December, 1929, putting on a program of ballet and songs of her native country in Los Angeles. www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/ildefonso-antonio-bermejo/...

The Manley, Australia Library blog has an article detailing the highlights of Seizo Kobayashi's career in Japan: " [...] Kobayashi (1877-1962) had an extraordinary career. He visited Australia several times. In 1912, he served on the Royal Navy ship HMS Collingwood as an attache. During WWI, he was awarded the US Navy Cross, for his actions in support of the Allied fleet. After WWI he represented Japan on the committee for disposal of enemy vessels, and no doubt saw to it that Japan received her share of Germany's naval fleet. He returned to Sydney in 1928 commanding the Idzumo, and hosted the NSW Premier, T R Bavin, to a dinner on board. He inspected the guard of honour at Government House. Clearly, he would have spoken English fluently, and the succession of diplomatic postings he undertook may well have had a deeper espionage role. Kobayashi rose to become an Admiral in the First Fleet of the Imperial Japanese Navy, and was a Rear-Admiral during the Japanese campaign in Manchuria. From September 1936 to November 1940, he was the Governor-General of Formosa (now Taiwan), where it is reported that he carried out a policy of 'Japanization'. He must have had blood on his hands. It must have been rare indeed for a Japanese combatant facing the US forces in WWII to have been decorated by them in WWI. Kobayashi resigned his post of Admiral in early 1945, and attempted to lead a group of officers of uncompromising bent, the Imperial Rule Assistance Political Society, hoping to persuade the Emperor not to surrender. The defeat of Japan put an end to his political hopes." manlylocalstudies.blogspot.com/search?q=kobayashi

In what was reported as a "Surprise to Society", Mrs. Hasell Borwick, younger daughter of Mr Lewis Cruger Hasell, and Mrs Mary Mason Hasell, became the bride of the Consul General of the Netherlands in New York, Adrian van de Sande-Bakhuyzen (1874-1951). After receiving their marriage license from City Hall, they immediately went to St. Mark's Church where they were married on February 18, 1915. The groom was 40 years old, the bride was 25. The bride was the former Mary Mason Hasell, and was a great great-grandaughter of the late Mrs. Mason Jones ("Lady Mary"). She made her début in 1907.  In 1908 she married George Borwick of London, heir of Sir Robert Borwick of Cumberland, England. They divorced in February, 1914, after some marital charges and counter-charges in London courts entertained London society-watchers. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] Mr. van de Sande-Bakhuyzen was the son of Dr. H. G. (Hendricus Gerardus) van de Sande-Bakhuyzen (1838-1923), a distinguished astronomer in the Netherlands. [6] Mr. Adrian van de Sande-Bakhuyzen served several posts as Consulate General, including Hong Kong, and New York. In February, 1916, Mrs.van de Sande-Bakhuyzen accompanied her husband to a new post as Consul General of the Netherlands at Singapore. [7] [8] [9] In July, 1919, Mrs. van de Sande-Bakhuyzen announced her divorce to Adrian and her marriage to R.A.D. Cort van der Linden in Edinburgh. Her husband is a son of Holland's Prime Minister, and is now studying music and composition in Holland. [10] At this point I refer to the bride as "Mrs. Mary Mason Hasell Borwick van de Sande-Bakhuyzen R.A.D. Cort van der Linden", however The New York Times refers to her as Mrs. Cort van der Linden. In October, 1921, Mrs. van der Linden returned to America to make her acting debut in a new play, "We Girls". She reportedly will be acting the part of "a society girl with cynical sayings". Her stage name is to be "Mary Hazel" (her maiden name was Mary Hasell). It was said she met with "much opposition" from her family in going on stage. WE GIRLS, a comedy in three acts, opened on Broadway, November 9, 1921, at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The New York Times review was good. I saw no mention of Mrs. van der Linden in the cast – by any name.

On March 17, 1915, the 15,000 ton superdreadnaught USS Pensylvania was launched at the Newport News (Virginia) Shipbuilding Drydock Company. It was the largest battleship ever launched anywhere in the world. Miss Elizabeth Ludoff Kolb (1896-1979) of Germantown, Pennsylvania, daughter of Louis J. Kolb of Philadelphia and a senior at National Park Seminary in Forest Glen, Maryland, had been invited to the launching ceremonies by Pennsylvania Governor Brumbaugh (term 1915-1919), who called her "the most beautiful and sweetest girl in Pennsylvania". Nineteen years young, Elizabeth was the official "sponsor" of the ship, which, as far as I can tell, means she offered the name for the ship.

I'm finding a Harriet Edna Oonk from Cincinnati, but not why she was newsworthy...

Harriet E. Oonk (1875-1958) of Cincinnati Ohio, was the featured photographer in the July, 1916, issue of PORTRAIT, a magazine published by Ansco. [1] "Almost every issue featured a portrait of a U.S. or Canadian photographer on the cover, an appreciative profile, including the photographer's endorsement of Ansco's Cyko paper, and one or more examples of the photographer's work. "Seventeen women (out of one hundred and forty-two photographers), were honored with cover stories".[2]  This may have been Harriet Oonk's cover portrait. Also in July, 1916, at the Thirty-Sixth Annual Convention of The Photographers' Association of America, held in Cleveland, Harriet was named as the secretary and treasurer of the Womens Federation for the coming year. [3] Harriet operated a photography studio at 1012 East McMillan Street, in Cincinnati, at least from 1908-1915. [4] Harriet likely moved to California. The 1931 South Orange County (California) City Directory lists a Harriet E. Oonk, photographer, at 2038b North Main Street, in Santa Ana, California. An older sister, Alice C. Oonk, also resided at the same address. The 1932 North Orange County (California) City Directory lists a Harriet E. Oonk, at 325 East Center Street, in Anaheim, California. [5] [6] [7] If the listing is the same person, Harriet Edna Oonk was born in Ohio, July 6, 1875, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G.(?) Oonk (née Buchenbus). She died at the age of 83 in Orange County, California, on December 27, 1958. [8] The Smithsonian American Art Museum / National Portrait Gallery Library maintains a folder for a "Harriet Oonk, b. 1875". Further research is necessary to discover the contents of that folder.

sad how the parents seem to be disconnected to the children. the mother has the baby perched on her lap and her arms folded, and the father almost seems to be leaning away from the young girl.

Some of this , maybe a lot, is informed by the long camera exposures of the day.  In most of these photos, the subject assumes a fixed position with the arms usually resting firmly somewhere or otherwise supported.  There were also portrait customs which dictated that the subjects of a portrait like this shouldn't be smiling or showing teeth. The father in this one is in a chair, the older daughter on a bench, supported by leaning against him.  His head tilt slightly away from her could also be partly due to the saxhorn between them, sticking up over his shoulder.
Because of those issues, I don't read a whole lot into this about their relationship.

He was married, in Washington County, Ind., to Mary Hays, whose parents settled in Brown Township, Washington County, in 1817. To this union were born four sons and three daughters. Mr. Wires has always been engaged in farming and stock-raising. Samuel Wires, son of Cryounce, spent his youth upon his father's farm, receiving the benefits of a good education. In 1864 he enlisted in Company H, One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Indiana Volunteer Infantry, and served for six months. Since his return home he has taught sixteen terms of school, and is one of the most popular and successful educators in Lawrence County. He also farms to some extent, owning 104 acres of land in Bono Township. He takes an active interest in the improvement of live stock, and is the owner of an English coach horse said by many to be the best general purpose horse in the county. Note the stricken "Seneg" in the caption... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senegalese_Tirailleurs The Senegalese Tirailleurs (French: Tirailleurs Sénégalais) were a corps of colonial infantry in the French Army recruited from Senegal, French West Africa and throughout west, central and east Africa, the main province of the French colonial empire. The noun tirailleur, which translates as "skirmisher", was a designation given by the French Army to indigenous infantry recruited in the various colonies and overseas possessions of the French Empire during the 19th and 20th centuries. Despite recruitment not being limited to Senegal, these infantry units took on the adjective "sénégalais" since that was where the first black African Tirailleur regiment had been formed. The first Senegalese Tirailleurs were formed in 1857 and served France in a number of wars, including World War I (providing around 200,000 troops, more than 135,000 of whom fought in Europe and 30,000 of whom were killed) and World War II. Other tirailleur regiments were raised in French North Africa from the Arab and Berber populations of Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco, they were called Tirailleurs algériens or Turcos. Tirailleur regiments were also raised in Indochina, they were called Vietnamese, Tonkinese or Annamites Tirailleurs.

Why "neutral" ?

I'd guess the caption was done after the sinking of the Lusitania in May 1915, and the writer was trying to be ironic. If the caption was done years later, possibly the writer knew the fate of the ship: www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?153501
Interesting, thanks!
The Netherlands were not involved in WWI. But it gave shelter for many refugees.

It does seem that a war of words was happening in February, 1915 (where the photo is in the Bain flow), so I think it's more likely that the caption was written then. From the Wikipedia article on HMS Lusitania: "1915 The official warning issued by the Imperial German Embassy about travelling on Lusitania. By early 1915 a new threat began to materialize: submarines. At first they were used by the Germans only to attack naval vessels, and they achieved only occasional – but sometimes spectacular – successes. Then the U-boats began to attack merchant vessels at times, although almost always in accordance with the old cruiser rules. Desperate to gain an advantage on the Atlantic, the German government decided to step up their submarine campaign. On 4 February 1915 Germany declared the seas around the British Isles a war zone: from 18 February allied ships in the area would be sunk without warning." This was not wholly unrestricted submarine warfare since efforts would be taken to avoid sinking neutral ships." It is definitely ironic that this very ship (under a French flag and named La Dives) was sunk by the Germans in January, 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Lusitania#International_reaction

Could be.  The entire Bain collection thus far is captioned in the same block printing, so I assumed somebody cataloged it all at a later date.  But it's just as likely that the same person worked there for years and cataloged it as it was created.  (Maybe the LOC knows for sure...?)

Whichever, it seems that the caption-writer was saying that at this point, "neutral" was just a word.  And of course, remember that Belgium was a neutral just like the Netherlands when the war broke out -- it just happened to be in the way.

Yes, maybe LOC can chime in on this point.  My understanding is that there is also a captioin card for each negative that is not online.  Perhaps these cards are filled out contemporaneously to the negative arriving in the collection, and the caption directly on the negative is a later transcription,.
Thanks all. We will investigate.

From what I understand, the negative would be hand-lettered and numbered first, so that the prints sent out to Bain's news photo subscribers would have basic caption info and an ID number handy as part of the image. We have a card catalog with hand-written entries made by Bain staff, but they are a subject index to the negatives, and it seems likely that the entries were added after the prints were made. As an example, the top of the card might say Christmas and below that is a list of inked numbers for negatives related to that topic. (I'll check next week at the Library and see if I can find which subject card listed this negative and post it here.) We also have a set of caption cards typed by LOC staff 40-50 years ago when they went through the negatives systematically. They combined and often shortened info found on the negative, the old paper sleeve for the negative, and the subject index. These typed cards are the source for the current captions you see in Flickr, even with their typos. It's been great to have a "positive" version of the negative (the digitized image) and the caption card info side-by-side now for easier comparison. We change the caption titles now to match what's written on the negatives. Best of all, we can add the fuller names and subject info that you all provide to the records, too! -- Helena (LOC)

A NEW GERMAN SOPRANO Mme. Melanie Kurt Appears at the Metropolitan Opera in "Tristan" The Metropolitan Opera House has acquired a remarkably fine artist in Mme. Melanie Kurt, the German dramatic soprano, who made her first appearance here last evening in a performance of "Tristan and Isolde". — The New York Times, February 2, 1915   Melanie Kurt (1880–1941) was an Austrian opera singer (soprano). She first studied to become a pianist in her native City of Vienna before starting to take singing lessons. From 1897 to 1900 she only appeared as a pianist. Later she went to Berlin, and London where she studied and performed with renowned opera singers. In 1914 she was at the peak of her career when she joined the Metropolitan Opera in New York City, where she succeeded Olive Fremstad as the company's leading Wagner soprano for three years. When America entered World War I in 1917, Wagner operas were banned as being too German. Torn by the war, Kurt remained in the US until 1919 before returning to Germany. — Excerpted from Wikipedia.

Jefferson Lasher, a driver for the Ward Baking Co., had a sudden memory lapse while testifying at a state hearing about conspiracy (price fixing) among New York's wholesale bakeries.
It must have been a cold hearing room.  Everyone looks bundled up.

Lasher was brought in by process servers at 4:15 p.m. on February 17th, 1915 and tried to slip out. However, the referee had him chased down and returned. At issue was whether he insisted that the stores he delivered to raise the price of a loaf from 5 to 6 cents. He did testify that his boss had told him to do so. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10916FF395C1373...
Henry Heinzer was a statistician for the Produce Exchange, who testified in a state hearing about conspiracy among New York's wholesale bakeries.
George G. Fender was a New York groceryman who testified in the state hearing about conspiracy (price fixing) among New York wholesale bakeries.
Este se ve bien asustado....

He testifed on 2/17/15 that this fellow: ...his bread delivery driver, had come to his store at 209 Columbus and insisted that he raise the price of a loaf to six cents. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10916FF395C1373...

I think an educated guess on this one is that he is Alfred L. Russell of A.L. Russell, Inc. which published the reports of the New York Produce Exchange, a commodities market that traded, among many other things, in grain. In a 1918 Columbia U. publication, he is also identified has having been a member of the Exchange since 1883. By 1918 he was working for the Federal Food Administration Grain Corporation, which was in charge of wartime wheat and grain distribution. He is probably photographed here at the New York Attorney General's offices, where the inquiry into grain and bread prices, speculation and price-fixing had begun on February 16th, 1915. The Exchange's Chief Statistician, Henry Heinzer testified at the inquiry. books.google.com/books?id=n44hAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA384&d...

NYT of Feb 6, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03EFD6143EE033A... in column 4 includes a piece on the newly opened Varick House, a modern hotel for working women. The sewing room is mentioned. Also part of the 6-storey 8-room facility were a gymnasium with running track and a yard and basketball court.

The boarding house, located in the heart of what was then the factory district, was intended to provide wholesome, home-like lodging for "factory girls". It was built in memory of the Spring Street Presbyterian Church's late pastor in a charitable effort led by Wm. Sloane Coffin (wealthy father of theologian Wm. Sloane Coffin, Jr,) ., and two others.. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F2091EF73F5A15738... . By the late 20's it was an NYU men's dormitory. In 1937, it became the Salvation Army's Evangeline House, providing housing again for women of limited means, and later its Women's Lodge. It was demolished in the mid-70's. The Trump SoHo tower now stands on the site. wirednewyork.com/forum/showthread.php?t=8466&page=50 The Spring Street church, now demolished also , was part of the same block, north of Varick House. The Trump SoHo tower covers the entire block formerly occupied by the church and its affiliated buildings.

Turns out all tintypes are reversed, unless some kind of correcting lens was used: "Each tintype is usually a camera original, so the image is usually a mirror image, reversed left to right from reality. Sometimes the camera was fitted with a mirror or right-angle prism so that the end result would be right-reading." (from Wikipedia Tintype entry)

This soldier was my great grandfather's half brother.  HIs full name was Oneziphrus Swepson A. Brock.  Born April 19, 1843 in Lynnhaven, Princess Anne County, VA.  His father was Ransom Brock and mother was Jacomine Methusa Brown, who are buried in the Alanton section of Virginia Beach.  I have his mother's prayer book in my possession.  Hand written inside left front cover: Jacamine Brock's book July 6, 1862  "O my heart is sad and I am all alone. O shall I ever see this war ended shall ever see my boys again.
Thanks for adding that.  I guess she was one of the lucky mothers who did see her boys again.

More than two dozen homing pigeons were released in New York City on February 13, 1915, as part of the Poultry and Pigeon Show being held in Madison Square Garden. Officials of the show, pictured above, sent a message of peace, via homing pigeon, to President Wilson, in Washington, DC. On each pigeon's leg was a narrow strip of tissue paper bearing the message: "Universal peace soon will be a god-send". The message was signed by Colonel Lee Crandall. After their arrival in Washington, the pigeons were released the following day at 9:15AM, and almost all of them had arrived in New York City later that day. Three of the pigeons, which belonged to Fred C. Schmidt (pictured above) arrived simultaneously at their loft in Brooklyn at 3:20PM. That six-hour flight was considered to be a "fast flight". — The New York Times                       ( To see the next photo in this series, click here.)

Pixel Wrangler: thank you for the New York Times article describing what is shown in this image. JE Piper: The photo depicts people releasing pigeons from the roof of the second Madison Square Garden arena which was built at 26th Street and Madison Avenue. Designed by Stanford White, the building opened in 1890 and was demolished in 1925. This photo from the New York Public Library shows a similar roof area during the demolition: digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?1691083 We will add some additional information to the description when we update.

Reeves of Trinidad, Colorado.[1] Bo Sweeney (1862-1917) was a native of Missouri, practiced law and was a state representative (D) in Colorado, before moving to Seattle. www.loc.gov/pictures/item/00650023/ is the record for a set of family albums compiled by Eleanor Butler Alexander Roosevelt. Two (out of 25) have been digitized as volumes (including the one with a date range covering 1915). However, this event doesn't get a mention.

According to www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=15079271 and www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=43902746 Mrs Bourke Cockran was Anne Louisa Ide Cockran (1876 - 1945) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Clay_Ide#Family.2C_personal_l... indicates that she was his third wife and that they married in 1906. She was over twenty years his junior. In that Wikipedia page she has the middle initial H. A delightful tidbit is that she was born on Christmas Day. When her father, Henry Clay Ide, was governor in Samoa, Robert Louis Stevenson, who lived there, sent a delightful letter/contract to her father, donating her the middle name of Louisa and his birthday (since he was too old to have need of one!). See NYT of July 24, 1906 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9805EED9143DE733A...

Taking another (more successful) tack on Mrs. Blair. The New York Sun., February 05, 1915, Page 9 (see above) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1915-02-05/ed-... lists a Mrs JOHN Blair as one of the organizers. This makes sense since a Mrs. John Blair was chairman of the publicity committee of Woman's Suffrage in New York (at least in December 1916). See www.apimages.com/OneUp.aspx?st=k&kw=161202015 The woman on the left of the AP photo is certainly a possible match to the woman on the left here. An obituary for Mrs. John Blair, NYT, November 06, 1930 [needs subscription] also has a photo that matches select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70B13F83D5C117A... She was the former Miss Ida Chester Reid. Her husband was an actor, as mentioned in The New York Sun., April 26, 1910, Page 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1910-04-26/ed-... in a piece reporting that her sister Estelle had been found murdered on a beach in Naples, Italy. See www.ibdb.com/person.php?id=32216 for John Blair's Broadway career. So, I've convinced myself that Bain mis-identified the woman on the left of this photo. She is Mrs. John Blair not Mrs, Jas. (i.e. James) Blair. Aside to LoC: I believe there is also mis-identification on www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2001704315/ (a Bain photo not yet mounted on Flickr), captioned Suffragettes - Mrs. John Blair, Mrs. N. de R. Whitehouse, Mrs. J.L. Laidlaw. Of the three pictured, I think the names Bain wrote on the negative were swapped for the two outer women.
Votes For Women Votes for Mrs. John Blair @ swanq — you have my vote for Mrs. "John" Blair ;-) Here's another photograph of Mrs. John Blair from the September 15, 1917, issue of Vogue.

And, from the "small-world department" ;-) when Winston Churchill first visited New York in 1895, he stayed with Mr. Bourke Cockran, whose third wife is pictured above. Bourke Cockran was a lover of Jennie Churchill, Winston's mother. [1] On a return trip in 1900, Winston was again lavishly entertained by Bourke Cockran, who organized a dinner for him at the Waldorf. Winston received an invitation to dine with then New York Governor Theodore Roosevelt, who was related to his mother, Jennie Churchill.[2]  Theodore Roosevelt was also the father of Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., whose wife, Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., is in the above photograph.

She was an American ship seized by the British for for transporting what the defined as contraband untreaty.un.org/cod/riaa/cases/vol_III/1861-1869.pdf On March 15th the Seguranca cleared from New York for Rotterdam with cargo consisting principally of oil, lard, borax, sausage casings, hides, green apples, and green coffee. Britain often seized ships bound for neutral ports where items could then make their way to Germany. This caused a great deal of consternation in the US as violating free trade.

That cite also recounts the owner's similar bad luck with his other ship, the Dacia, seized by France in February, 1915 for carrying freight bound for Germany: A biographical sketch of the Seguranca, which leaves out her seizure by the Brits: "Seguranca (1889) (Official Number 116344) Launched in 1890 for the U.S. & Brazil S.S. Co. (Empire Line); seized for debts in April 1893 and laid up; bought by the Ward Line in December 1893; in service 1894 to 1898; chartered to U.S. Army in 1898; refitted and put back in service from 1898 to 1914. She was sold to the Winnett Operating Company in 1914 as transatlantic freighter, then sold to Seguranca S.S. Co. (Breitung & Co.) Chartered to Federal S.S. Co. in 1917, she was sold to Standard Commercial S.S. Co. in 1918 and damaged after grounding off Bermuda. Laid up, she briefly returned to service for J.G. Hitner in 1921 and was scrapped in 1923." www.wardline.com/page/page/4557567.htm

Assuming these pictures were taken by Germans/Austrians/Hungarians, it seems as though an interest in ethnology was already in place. See also next photo: Collected works of M.A. Czaplicka, Volume 4 books.google.com/books?id=XyYm3TbTg1oC&pg=PA106&l... discusses different types of "turks" in the pre-WWI Russian empire -- largely from the perspective of religious affiliation. But it suggests the complexity of racial and tribal groupings in that part of the world. Aside: Turkey, as the name for the modern republic, was only established after WWI. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Name_of_Turkey the name when used for a region was usually synonymous with Tartary in the Central Asian steppes. Between the 14th century and WWI, the Ottoman Empire covered those regions as well as modern Turkey and much of the Mediterranean and Middle East. Until the establishment of the Repblic of Turkey (1922) the words Turk and Turkish (or rather the equivalent in other languages) were used mainly as an ethnic designation and/or a class of language. More history at www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Tatars.aspx

Seems to have been taken with this shot, elsewhere in the bain collection and apparently not up yet on Flickr: lcweb2.loc.gov/service/pnp/ggbain/04600/04614v.jpg Written on both negatives is an inscription "Park Row", then possibly "near Pearl Street", Park Row is a bit south of Chinatown. Unlike the other Chinatown shots, this has no Chinese businesses or people who look particularly Chinese. I can't find a match for the printing company, but Nadel & Shimmel toy company is listed in the Polk City Directory for 1919 at 132 Park Row. They might have moved or occupied more than one building on the block. play.google.com/books/reader?id=EJw0AQAAMAAJ&printsec... rjones0856, swanq, artolog and lazygardens: Thank you for your research on these images of Chinatown in New York City. As rjones0856 states, the Church of the Transfiguration, appears in the background and is still located today at 25 Mott Street. The Port Arthur restaurant was at 7-9 Mott Street as shown in this old postcard: www.cardcow.com/311741/port-arthur-restaurant-7-9-mott-st... I think therefore that the shooting in the caption may refer to one which happened on Mott Street, rather than the one referred to in the New York Times article sent by lazygardens, which happened on Pell Street. A July 1910 shooting in the same block of Mott Street as shown in the Bain images is detailed in this New York Times article which also mentions the Port Arthur restaurant and the Church of the Transfiguration: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70611FD395D11738... However, probably more than one shooting occurred on Mott Street, so I don’t think we can pin it down to this one, given the lack of information in the Bain caption. But we can add some more details about the location of these two images in our description. Thanks for your help!

Looking for something more in the presumed date range of the picture, there was the planned execution of Eng Hing and Lee Dock of the Hop Sing tong who had been convicted of the February 12, 1912 murder of Lee Kay (nephew of the head of the On Leong tong) at 18 Mott Street, in revenge for a Hop Sing murder. They were scheduled for Sing Sing's electric chair on December 11, 1914 and there was a reprieve until February 5th, 1915. Fearing more shooting, there was a large police presence in Chinatown around the time of the re-scheduled execution. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30813F93E5C1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B11F73F5A1573...
if the damage was not from battlecruiser shells, then it was indeed bombs from zeppelins in the raid on Yarmouth en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombardment_of_Yarmouth_and_Lowestoft

Seems like it was the Zeppelin raid. This is likely not the battle linked to above, but the Zeppelin raid on Yarmouth and surrounding area on January 19, 1915. The raid, which killed 2 in Yarmouth and injured others, was the first aerial bombardment that killed people, and the first enemy action in England in 250 years, according to these accounts: www.kingslynn-forums.co.uk/viewtopic.php?f=14&t=1365&... www.gorlestonhistory.org.uk/worldwars/zeppelinairraid1915... The BBC used a slightly different photo, taken perhaps at the same time and the same spot, last January in a story about a plaque that was dedicated on the site of the bombing: www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-norfolk-16620650 A contemporary newspaper account: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/72969115

This is likely the "Knickerbocker Hotel Bread Line". Opened in 1906, The Knickerbocker Hotel was located at 1466 Broadway at the southeast corner of 42nd Street in New York City, The new hotel had 556 rooms but was organized around the dining and entertaining rooms on the lower three floors -- with 2,000 restaurant seats to feed the theater district traffic (with a gold dinner service for 48). [1] The back door to the hotel was on 41st Street, and some of the unemployed and hungry men, women and children would line up there, where they were given a little something to eat. As a run-up to America's entering World War I, there was record unemployment in New York City, and the winter of 1914-1915 was especially hard. The New-York Tribune reported on February 05, 1915:
"More than 1,400 men and 93 women were fed yesterday afternoon In the Hotel Knickerbocker bread line. Eighteen overcoats and twenty-seven suits of clothes were distributed to the more destitute men in the line by guests of the hotel. Two hundred articles of wearing apparel donated by women employees and guests of the hotel were distributed among the needy women and girls who joined the pitiful procession."
On some days, as many as 3,600 unemployed people would be waiting in the Knickerbocker Hotel bread line for something to eat. [2]

"The Serbian Hospitals' Fund, through which so much that is generous and beautiful has been done, was conceived and organized by Madame Slavko Grovitch. Since the outbreak of the war she has de- voted herself to relief work for Serbia." www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/ida-clyde-gallagher-clarke... Ida Clyde Gallagher Clarke. American women and the world war
The book cited by artolog indicates that she arrived in America in January 1915.

NYT of April 22, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E04E7D8153AE433A... spells her last name Grouitch. Her husband was the Minister of Foreign Affairs in Serbia during WWI, but was a diplomat before and after, for Serbia and, later, Yugoslavia -- including a spell in Washington.
hdl.loc.gov/loc.ndlpcoop/ichicdn.n064380 from the Chicago Daily News photo file, indicates that she visited Chicago in April 1915. The hat looks to be the same or very similar.

She was also an American, born in West Virginia as Mabel Gordon-Dunlop (1881-1956). She was an alumna of the University of Chicago, went to Greece to study archaeology, and there met her future husband, Slavko Gruitch (spelled variously, I'm also seeing Gruji´c). She gets a mention in John B. Allcock and Antonia Young, Black Lambs and Grey Falcons: Women Travellers in the Balkans (Berghahn Books 2001): p. 73.

The Grouitch spelling finds more, including an October 28, 1912 NYT piece about a previous visit.  This reveals that she is American, the former Miss Mabel Gordon-Dunlop of Clarksburg, West Va.  She graduated from the University of Chicago, lectured on archaeology and art, and traveled to Greece to study art in 1901.  There she met the Serbian Charge d'Affaires in Athens and they were married in 1902.
Appears to be taken at same place as:

Apparently this is Helena (or Yelena, or Jelena) Lozanich , daughter of Dr. Sima Lozanich, a Serbian diplomat. She married an American, John Whipple Frothingham. In 1914 she was appointed by the Serbian Red Cross to visit North America and raise funds. Her wedding was announced in the New York Times under the name Helen Losanitch, and that seems to be the spelling she used later in life. Here's a book published under her married name, letters she wrote during her travels in the US and Canada, 1915-1920: books.google.com/books/about/Mission_for_Serbia.html?id=f... Her much younger sister Stanka married a Scotsman, Patrick Maitland, the Earl of Lauderdale: www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2008/dec/08/conservatives-lor...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lodz Third largest city in Poland. "Despite the air of impending crisis preceding World War I, the city grew constantly until 1914. By that year it had become one of the most densely-populated industrial cities in the world—13,280 inhabitants per square kilometre (34,400 /sq mi). A major battle was fought near the city in late 1914, and as a result the city came under German occupation after 6 December..."

From ww1.m78.com/english version/lodz.html about the Battle of Lodz "On 11 November [1914] German offensive began. German three corps in all attacked Siberian 5th corps (Sidorin) located in the far south on the left wing of 1st army. Meanwhile, two third of Siberian 5th were taken prisoners. But Ruzski did not think it serious, but rather of a feint ascribing this failure to the weakness of second line corps." From what this site says the Russians regrouped in Lodz at one point and captured large numbers of Germans, but tenacity of the German Reserves led to an escape and more bitter fighting (in bitter cold), with the Germans victorious and the Russians retreating from Lodz in late November to behind the Vistula river.
More on the Battle of Lodz: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA_(1914)

Another of the witnesses called before the Commission on Industrial Relations (Walsh Commission) for their January, 1915 hearings at New York's City Hall. Lawson was a member of the international executive committee of the United Mine Workers Union. He was a leader of the labor actions in Ludlow, Colorado at the time of the Ludlow Massacre. As he expected to be charged with crimes for his activies at Ludlow, he declined to testify in detail, but submitted a statement to the Commission. His testimony is at www.archive.org/stream/industrialrelati08unitrich#page/71... Later in 1915, he was convicted of a murder ocurring during the labor unrest, but his conviction was overturned 2 years later. Biographical sketch at: eadsrv.denverlibrary.org/sdx/pl/doc-tdm.xsp?id=WH215_d0e3...

Less than 100 years ago (and less than 60 miles from my house), Ludlow is a bit of our history that should be taught. Anybody traveling I-25 north of Trinidad, Colorado can visit the memorial, which is only 2 minutes or so west of the interstate. I'd recommend reading the guestbook, which has never failed to move and surprise me. I'd never seen an image of John Lawson; thanks for sharing. -- Found in a search. (?)

It was actually in WWI with the advent of gas attacks that facial hair fell out of fashion: gas masks do not work well with beards and mustaches. Bic corporation made a lot of money from soldiers in that war.

Looks like another of Crown Prince Wilhelm. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William,_German_Crown_Prince "His Imperial and Royal Highness Friedrich Wilhelm Victor August Ernst Hohenzollern, the Crown Prince of Prussia was best known to most people outside Germany as Little Willie, a slender youth with a long nose and no chin. He was seen in most of his photographs dressed as a Death's Head Hussar, and caricaturists generally drew him in that uniform, which suited his long and lanky fignre. At eighteen he "came of age" and assumed the Royal and Imperial dignities and precedence, and in the same year (1900) was made a Lieutenant in the 1st Foot Guards, served three years in that rank, became a Cavalry Captain for four years, and a Major for six. His name appeared on the lists of eleven or twelve different German regiments, and he also belonged to the llth Spanish Dragoons. Up to the outbreak of the Great War he could be described as a keen regimental soldier up to a certain point. He was advanced to the command of the Death's Head Hussars at Danzig. Without any real knowledge of war he was quickly jumped up in rank from commander of a cavalry regiment to lieutenantgeneral, and given command of the largest group of army-corps." www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/europe/totenkopf.htm

Claire L. Runkel (1890-1936) and Oscar F. Grab (1886–1958) were married on March 23, 1915, at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in New York City. Claire was the daughter of Herman Runkel (1853-1918) and Victoria Rebecca Runkel (née Lopez) (1859-1927), of 150 W. 79th Street in New York City. Mr. Runkel was of the firm Runkel Brothers, chocolate manufacturers. "Oscar F. Grab , born Oskar Grab, was an Austro-Hungarian immigrant, United States citizen, and fashion executive. He was a saloon passenger aboard Lusitania who saw the torpedo impact the ship on May 7, 1915.. He saw lifeboats upset on the starboard side and jumped into the water instead of taking a chance in the lifeboats. He was rescued and survived the Lusitania disaster." His wife was not traveling with him. "Oscar and Claire moved in with Claire’s parents that October. The couple had two children, Victoria, born in 1916, and Donald born in 1923. Claire also authored a book, Fancies of a Child by a Child "By 1928, Oscar’s fashion company, O. F. Grab & Company, was a million-dollar business that had branches in France and Belgium and was employing 250 people. That year, Grab transferred his business to 14 top employees when he left the firm to become executive vice-president of the Lefcourt-Normandie National Bank. The next year, Grab became president of the Normandie National Securities Corporation, an investment affiliate of the bank." After the market crash, Oscar ran a styling service for fabric houses in New York from 1932 to World War II,. His office was in Paris, France. — Excerpted and compiled   [N Y Times] [N Y Times] [The Lusitania Resource] [Find A Grave]   [Obituary, NY Times]

Probably the Sava River (a tributary of the Danube), near Novi Sad today in northern Serbia and formerly Neusatz (in Austro-Hungary). From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia#Balkan_Wars_and_World_War_I Serbia won the first major battles of World War I, including the Battle of Cer and Battle of Kolubara – marking the first Allied victories against the Central Powers in World War I. This is Mrs. Mina C. Van Winkle (1875-1932), of Newark, New Jersey, leading the New Jersey Women's Political Union in the "Handing On The Torch of Victory" demonstration, on August 7, 1915. The New York Union supplied a large bronze torch which Mrs. H. O. Havemeyer, representing New York, took with her on a tugboat half way across the Hudson River, where she was met by a New Jersey tug, the A. W. Smith. bearing Mrs. Van Winkle, to whom the torch was delivered. It was sent about the State to twenty or more towns where the Union had branches and its arrival was made the occasion for an outdoor reception and mass meeting. There is a fanciful article about the steps (and missteps) of this event in The New York Times. A close-up of Mrs Van Winkle holding the torch on the tugboat is in the Bain Collection at the Library of Congress: "Mrs. Van Winkle and Suffrage torch"                                               by Bain/LOC   ↓ Click On This Icon to Reload Photo   Taken a few years later, there is a photo on Flickr of Mrs. Van Winkle in a Uniform of Food Administration by The U.S. National Archives, on Flickr Commons: "Mrs. Mina C. Van Winkle of Newark, New Jersey, in Uniform of Food Administration. She Was President of Woman's Political Union of New Jersey 8 Years and Is Now Head of Lecture Bureau of Food Administration."           by The U.S. National Archives   Born Wilhelmina ("Mina") Caroline Ginger, Mina graduated from the social work program of the New York School of Philanthropy in 1905.  In 1906 she became the second wife of Abraham Van Winkle (1838-1915), wealthy president of a chemical manufacturing company (and a widower 36 years her senior) who had financially supported the Bureau of Associated Charities. Her husband died in 1915, at age 76. The following year the Washington D.C. Police Department began to hire policewomen. In 1918, a woman’s bureau was established and Mina Van Winkle was one of four members of the Bureau. In 1919, Van Winkle became the Bureau’s director, with an initial rank of detective sergeant (and, by December 1920, as a lieutenant). The Bureau’s initial responsibilities included “girl welfare work,” prevention and detection of store crimes, and supervision of movie theatres, dance halls, and similar places. However, its greatest emphasis was on casework. Van Winkle stated that “prevention and protection are more primary than prosecution, and those who have done wrong should be intelligently aided toward a better life.” From 1919 until the time of her death, she was president and chief financial contributor of the International Association of Policewomen. The organization was disbanded following her death, but was resurrected in 1956 as the International Association of Police Women (known since 1969 as the International Association of Women Police).
