From the chronological list of France's leading statesmen; the dates given are the periods of said rule. Although the title 'prime minister' was only officially introduced with the Fifth Republic, it can - and normally is - used to describe all of these individuals
1892 - 1893 Alexandre Joseph Ribot (2 terms)
1895 - 1895 Alexandre Joseph Ribot (3rd term)
1914 &nbspAlexandre Joseph Ribot (4th term)
1917 &nbspAlexandre Félix Joseph Ribot (5th term)
Ribot was brought in as prime minister for a few days in June 1914 following the collapse of the Doumergue government, and returned to power again in March 1917, following the fall of Briand. Ribot's final ministry was during the most dismal part of the First World War, seeing the failure of the Nivelle Offensive and the famous mutiny of the French soldiers which followed. Dismissed in September and replaced by minister of war Paul Painlevé, Ribot continued as foreign minister for a month before resigning in October.

Typo in the title spelling of Château. If you look at the photos on Wiki en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Chambord you'll see that this is part of the roof, directly above the double helix staircase. The staircase is reputed to have been designed by Leonardo da Vinci for Francis I to enable the king to get visitors in and out of his apartments without meeting each other. The staircase is the same shape as the DNA double helix.
Caption spelling should be: "Chambord Chateau".

It was in the news in April, 1915, when it was siezed by the French government as the property of an enemy of France. The chateau had become the property of the Duke of Parma, who in 1915 was Elias, Duke of Parma, who was then serving in the Austrian army. news.google.com/newspapers?id=1ostAAAAIBAJ&sjid=85wFA... Details of the litigation (which lasted until 1930) emanating from the sequestration of the chateau at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elias,_Prince_of_Parma

A photo dated 1915 of what might well be the actor, taken by Arnold Genthe (who took portrait photos of many actors), is at www.loc.gov/pictures/item/agc1996004197/PP/ That photo looks older, but there are similarities, and makeup can be deceiving.

There is a Robert Lee Keeling (1865 or 1870 to ?), miniaturist and brother to Rose Keeling Hutchins, wife of the Washington Post founder Stilson Hutchins. He and she are mentioned regularly in the society pages of the New York Times in this era. I haven't seen anything mentioning that he was also a movie actor, so they could well be different people. The actor's movie career doesn't seem to have started until 1918, when the miniaturist was 48, while Mrs. Hutchins' 1926 obituary describes her brother as "the miniaturist of New York City." However, the miniaturist R.L. Keeling was in some professional productions in the 1890's. A profile of the miniaturist at select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60C13F6385D1373... As an artist and wealthy socialite, one can imagine him as the subject of offbeat portraits such as this one and the one by Genthe. However, this portrait in not of a 45 year old man, so if it is the same subject as Genthe's, it was taken long before 1915.

@artolog, More fodder for detective work. I found a picture (and profile as a member of society in Washington DC) of the miniaturist at books.google.com/books?id=gm4eAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA250&l... in an 1898 issue of The International. It could be the same man at the same sort of age. And NYT September 19, 1897 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0D14FC3B5D11738... reports the death of a wife (a widow 20 years his senior) with whom he lived briefly before separating. It mentions that he was on the stage before taking up painting as a career.

The history of tweed for gentlemen's jackets doesn't really help with the dating. According to www.harristweed.org/fabric_hist.htm marketing of the fabric outside the Scottish islands began around 1850 and an improved loom was introduced in 1903. 1903-1906 saw a boom and led to the establishment of the Harris Tweed trademark around 1910. So this could possibly be a photo of a fashion leader around 1900. By 1915, I think tweed would have been common for outdoor activities, at least in UK society. NYT of May 12, 1902 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0813FF385412738... reports that the miniaturist was to sail for London to paint a miniature of King Edward. So that Robert Lee Keeling could have had a jacket tailored for him while there.

Mulligan

From a source quoted on Wikipedia, here is a contemporary description of Mulligan Stew: "Another traveler present described the operation of making a 'mulligan.' Five or six hobos join in this. One builds a fire and rustles a can. Another has to procure meat; another potatoes; one fellow pledges himself to obtain bread, and still another has to furnish onions, salt and pepper. If a chicken can be stolen, so much the better. The whole outfit is placed in the can and boiled until it is done. If one of the men is successful in procuring 'Java,' an oyster can is used for a coffee tank, and this is also put on the fire to boil. Incidentally, it may be mentioned that California hobos always put a 'snipe' in their coffee, to give it that delicate amber color and to add to the aroma. 'Snipe' is hobo for the butt end of a cigar that smokers throw down in the streets. All hobos have large quantities of snipes in their pockets, for both chewing and smoking purposes. A 'beggar stew' is a 'mulligan,' without any meat."
Thanks bior for the tantalizing description of this delicacy. And thank you cwalter54 for noting the spelling error.  We will correct the spelling in the record the next time we update.
Oh, one more thing.  Does anyone know the origin of "Hotel de Gink"? One of the hobos has a handmade sign on his cap that says "....Gink"  Is it a hobo term as well?

Nona Hazelhurst McAdoo (1892 or 1893-1971) was the daughter of Senator William G. McAdoo. Her stepmother Eleanor Wilson was the daughter of President Woodrow Wilson. wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=REG&db=wo... She married four times: "in 1917 to Ferdinand de Mohrenschildt, one-time official of the Russian Embassy in Washington, who died in 1919. In 1928 Mrs. de Mohrenschildt was married in this city to Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist and founder of the Body-and-Soul Clinic at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, who was the object of a protest of the authorities of the Protestant Episcopal Church for his use of the church for healing clinics." She divorced Edward Spencer Cowles (note spelling). In 1935, she married Francis Taylor, but they too divorced, in 1939. Her last husband was Darragh A. Park. wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=wo... homepages.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~asbellm/genealogy/fam042... This photo must have been labeled long after 1915, if the subject is indeed Nona Hazelhurst McAdoo de Mohrenschildt Cowles (Taylor)(Park).

The negative bears 1915 and 1927 dates (rootsweb cite says elsewhere Cowles marriage was 8/13/27), so the Bain labelers must have have expanded her name as she added husbands. She seems to have been buried in the same plot with her first and last husbands, as well as her mother. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=63959244

True!  You can almost see the name grow in the handwritten caption--started out as "Nona McAdoo" (that part is bigger, brighter, and centered over the image), then the first husband's long surname was added, then that whole segment was parenthesized and "Mrs. E. S. Coles" was squeezed into the remaining space.  No wonder they spelled Cowles wrong in all that... ;)

Could be the former Margarita Armstrong, wife of Anthony J. Drexel (son of the Drexel who founded Drexel University). In December 1915, she was in the news in association with a judgment in London allowing her to recover money from her husband (who had taken up residence in Europe) under a separation deed. See New-York tribune., December 17, 1915, Page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-12-17/ed-...

Photographer appears to be Marceau. See rcc.psc.sc.edu/index.php?action=showPhotographer&id=28 An interesting tidbit: "Because of Marceau's liberal administrations of champagne, his skill as a raconteur, and his sociable nature, he immediately became a fixture in the associational world of the profession in New York. In 1905 he and Pirie McDonald organized the Professional Photographers Society of New York State and served as its First Vice-President. With B. J. Falk and Pirie MacDonald, Marceau organized the Copyright League that lobbied Congress for stronger rights protections for photographers against the appropriation of their images by newspapers. It is he that recommended that a c with a circle around it and the photographer's name on the front of an image serve as the public claim that an image was copyright protected." There is a C in a circle near his name and another at lower right. Note: the photographs of Isabel B. Gardner and Mrs. Henry Pierson in this batch appear to have the same studio background.

Alternatively, she could be the former Marjorie Gould, who married the younger Anthony J. Drexel. The Tacoma times., February 22, 1915, Page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88085187/1915-02-22/ed-... has a picture of Marjorie that could be in this hat. The photo is a Marceau photo, although not the same as this one. Pittsburgh Press news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19150223&... has the same piece with better image quality.

The wedding mentioned in the piece that features the "aureole" hat took place on January 6, 1915 and "Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Jr., formerly Miss Marjorie Gould" was matron of honour. This looks like an outfit for a matron of honor. See NYT of Dec 16, 1914 announcing the plans. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0614FA3F5C13738... A report of the wedding at fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... describes Mrs. Drexel's outfit: "of orchid colored satin. Her hat consisted of a deep crown of the same shade of satin and a wide brim of of wavy gold net. She carried a bouquet of mauve orchids, and over her shoulders and corsage fell two long strings of pearls." I think this is the former Miss Marjorie Gould.
Definitely.. that's the outfit.

Leonard Wood (October 9, 1860 – August 7, 1927) was a physician who served as the Chief of Staff of the United States Army, Military Governor of Cuba and Governor General of the Philippines. Early in his military career, he received the Medal of Honor. Wood also holds officer service #2 in the Regular Army (John Pershing holds officer service #1). He was present at the 1906 First Battle of Bud Dajo. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonard_Wood Colonel Arthur Hale Woods (January 29, 1870 – May 12, 1942) was an American educator, journalist, military and law enforcement officer. One of the most prominent police reformers during the early 20th century, he served as deputy New York City Police Commissioner from 1907 to 1909 and later became New York City Police Commissioner in 1914. During his time with the NYPD, he was largely responsible for initiating criminology and sociology in modern policing. In his later years, Woods worked with the Division of Military Aeronautics and was involved in government committees on unemployment under the administrations of Presidents Warren G. Harding and Herbert Hoover. Woods was also an important public servant as trustee for the Board of Education and presided as president and chairman of the board of Rockefeller Center. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Hale_Woods
Police Commissioner Woods was also present. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801EEDD1538E633A...

She was Clara Dolores Machain, before becoming Mrs. George Washington Lopp. In the New York Times story of 2/3/15, she is referred to as Clara "Washington-Lopp", sender of two 15,000 pound shipments of cigarettes, cigars and tobacco to soldiers at the front. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9500E3D91538E633A... A newspaper article from May, 1916 describes her husband as shooting and wounding her and his stepdaughter in an argument about divorce. She is described as being known as "Lady Nicotine" by grateful soldiers for whom she had collected millions of cigarettes. news.google.com/newspapers?id=j9ExAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_uIFA... Other newspaper articles describe the weapon as a chisel. One account says she was Paraguayan by birth, her father being the the Paraguayan minister in Paris.

He is likely photographed in New York City Hall (as were the following pictures of Ida Tarbell and Samule Untermyer) in connection with the Commission on Industrial Relations hearings, at which he eventually testified. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commission_on_Industrial_Relations

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ida_M._Tarbell Ida Minerva Tarbell (November 5, 1857 – January 6, 1944) "was an American teacher, author and journalist. She was known as one of the leading "muckrakers" of the progressive era, work known in modern times as "investigative journalism". She wrote many notable magazine series and biographies. She is best known for her 1904 book The History of the Standard Oil Company, which was listed as No. 5 in a 1999 list by New York University of the top 100 works of 20th-century American journalism." tarbell.allegheny.edu/treckel.html is an essay on her life by a history professor from Allegheny College, Tarbell's alma mater.

On Jan 19, 1915, she gave testimony at the Federal Commission on Industrial Relations at "the City Hall" according to the NYT of Jan 20, 1915. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E02E4DF1E3FE633A... I had immediately thought this picture might have been taken there, since it is clearly in a formal location and she seems to have notes on her lap. However, the NYT reports that she was in a BLACK tailored suit and hat to match and this doesn't seem to be black. But, given that one of the dates on the other photo in this batch is 1/19/15, I am back to thinking this is at City Hall. I am assuming the City Hall is in NYC, because the newspaper article doesn't indicate any other city.

Samuel Untermyer testified before the same Federal Commission on Industrial Relations as Ida Tarbell (neighboring photo). He appeared on Jan 18, the day before her. See NYT of 1/19/1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40A11FF3E5C13738... "URGES FEDERAL REIN ON BIG FOUNDATIONS; Untermyer Also Condemns Wall St. Control of Industries at Commission's Inquiry. "

The Walsh Commission, (Commission on Industrial Relations) was "created by the U.S. Congress on August 23, 1912. The commission studied work conditions throughout the industrial United States between 1913 and 1915. The final report of the Commission, published in eleven volumes in 1916, contain tens of thousands of pages of testimony from a wide range of witnesses" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commission_on_Industrial_Relations The 1916 report is available online and contains the testimony of Untermyer and the others pictured in the Bain Collection. Interesting primary source material on the views of Labor and the captains of industry in an age before most of the present-day legal controls over workplace conditions were in place. www.archive.org/stream/industrialrelati08unitrich#page/74...
And a sculptured fountain, once on his estate, given by his children to Central Park: www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/north-end/unte...

This may be the house of Arthur Capper at 1035 Topeka Boulevard. When he served as governor from 1915 to 1919, he lived in his own house rather than the governor's mansion -- which looked nothing like this. See www.kshs.org/p/cool-things-stained-glass-windows/10277

In Kansas: A Guide to the Sunflower State (a 1939 publication of the Federal Writers Project), books.google.com/books?id=prI_kG_QmvoC&pg=PA290&l... Capper's house, then the headquarters of WIBW Radio & TV, stations he owned, is described as "a two-story limestone and concrete structure of the Italian villa type." So this could well be that house. According to this publication, the house was on the NW corner of Topeka Blvd and 11th St, designed by Root & Seimans [sic -- actually Siemens] of Kansas City and completed in 1912. The following governor also lived in the house -- while Capper was a Senator. cjonline.com/stories/120202/wib_history.shtml indicates that WIBW moved in in 1934 after remodeling, and remained there for 20 years.

New York Republican politician, b. 1860.  Served on the Committee on Legislation, State Department of Agriculture and Markets; president New York State Agricultural Society.

A 1910 biographical sketch from "New York state men : biographic studies and character portraits, Volume 2 By Frederick Simon Hills" books.google.com/books?id=QlxKAAAAYAAJ&dq=c.%20fred%2... "C FRED BOSHART Agriculturist Member of Assembly from Lewis County was born at Lowville Lewis County NY September 17 1860 son of Charles D Boshart farmer and Margaret Quackenbushl Boshart His preparatory education was received at Lowville Academy and in 1884 he was graduated from Cornell University with the degree of Bachelor of Agriculture Mr Boshart has for many years been prominent in the Republican politics of Lewis County In 1904 and 1905 he was Superv1sor of Lowville and in 1905 he was elected to the State Assembly to which he was re elected in 1906 1907 1908 and 1909 Since 1907 he has been chairman of the Assembly Committee on Agriculture and has also served as a member of the Committees on Ways and Means Taxation and Retrenchment Canals and Labor and Industry In 1907 he was appointed a member of the joint legislative commission to investigate the general subject of taxation Mr Boshart is a director and vice president of the First National Bank of Lowville member Lowville Lodge No 134 F & AM Watertown Com mandery No 11 KT Media Temple AAONMS Lowville Lodge No 759 IOOF and of the Lowville Club He married Clara Amelia Smiley October 20 1887 Mrs Boshart is a daughter of Amos V Smiley of Lowville editor and former Member of Assembly Children Charles R and Margaret A Address Lowville." ... In his later life, he served several terms as the president of the New York State Agriculturat Society and held some other agriculture-related posts in state government.. He died in 1928. Lengthy obituary at: fultonhistory.com/Process%20small/Newspapers/Lowvile%20Ny...(406).PDF [New York Times (AP) obituary incorrectly states that he was State Commissioner of Agriculture.]

Charles succeeded to the thrones in November 1916, when his grand-uncle, Franz Josef I of Austria died. The First Ostend Raid (part of Operation ZO) was the first of two attacks by the Royal Navy on the German-held port of Ostend during the late spring of 1918 during the First World War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Ostend_Raid

The airship looks like it's pasted in, too.  Since this is earlier than 1918 in the general Bain picture flow, this might be an illustration from closer to the time the Germans took Ostend in mid-October, 1914.  Are those German flags flying and German soldiers on the embankment?
At bottom left is the logo of Neue Photographische Gesellschaft m.b.H. (NPG) de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neue_Photographische_Gesellschaft a Berlin company. Hence this is probably a German photograph.
I wondered about the date too..  I didn't see an earlier raid so that makes the most sense.  It must have been an active place during the war!
good catch, swanq.. The subject matter is pretty pro-German as well.

From what I can see, although I haven't found a good timeline, the Belgians had abandoned Antwerp in October 10, 1914, and of the British who had been coming to their aid in Ostend, some were taken off by sea and others retreated on land. A week later there are reports of the British navy attacking Ostend and the Germans bringing in new guns. One illustration of what was going on at this time is at www.historyofwar.org/articles/weapons_HMS_Humber.html The British expected to reoccupy Ostend soon, but that did not happen.

Felix Tony McWhirter (1853-1915) was a banker from Indianapolis (born in Tennessee); also a newspaper editor, college professor, and politician. His wife was Luella Frances Smith (b. 1859) of Indiana; she served on the board of directors for the People's Deposit Bank, along with Sallie Lemon, another partner's wife--apparently they were the first two women bank directors in Indiana. Felix and Luella had three daughters and a son; both Felix and Luella were active in the Temperance movement. www.godeke.org/Psi_Phi/Ancestors_FelixMcWhirter.htm The Luella McWhirter Martin of Indianapolis in this story must surely have been a daughter (or granddaughter?) of the photo's subject: newground.iufoundation.iu.edu/articles/issue02/alt_layout...

Puzzling.
The 4th Earl died in December 1914, aged 75.  He was succeeded by his 7-yr-old grandson.  This seems unlikely to be either of them.

Resolved. NYT of September 26, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B13F73B5812738... has a piece on British (including Irish) peers who had been killed or were missing in action. It features this photo as the fifth Earl of Erne. It appears that Henry William Crichton, Viscount Crichton (1872 - 1914) went missing on November 1, 1914, before his father died. And so he was referred to as the 5th Earl. His son presumably waited until later to be given the title.

histfam.familysearch.org/getperson.php?personID=I57837&am... a genealogical entry has the note: TITLES: Succeeded father (while missing in action) as Earl Erne of Crom Castle [I.], title created 1789, see 'The Complete Peerage', vol. 5 p. 93 fn. c. and indicates that he was "reinterred at Wervico Nord by the Germans." Burke's Annual Register books.google.com/books?id=Wu33Rq5P-0wC&pg=RA1-PA176&a... indicates that the Foreign Office received a telegram in June 1916 via the American Embassy in Berlin that his body had been found and reinterred.
Yes, unusual story.. Succeeded his father, but was most likely dead at the time of his succession.
Thank you swanq for the interesting background information.  We may include it in the record.

See: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00E12F73F5A15738... 250,000 in Tie-up at Morning Rush Hour; Affects Whole City Short Circuit Starts Fire Three Packed Trains Stalled at 55th St. and Broadway Near Flames New York Times January 7, 1915 The worst accident in the history of the New York subways occurred yesterday morning, when one woman was killed and 210 persons weer overcome by smoke or trampled upon. Three crowded downtown trains weer stalled at 8:02 o'clock between the Columbus Circle and Fiftieth Street station by a short circuit which set fire to the insulation of electric wires and filled the tunnel with a dense acrid smoke.

Most of the buildings are now gone, with the exception of the Woodward (now Dream) Hotel, but the access grates to the subway (the only exit for the 250 trapped passengers) are still there. maps.google.com/maps?q=1261+broadway+new+york&hl=en&a...

The New York Times reported that one person, Ella Grady, was killed. We note that photographer George Grantham Bain, like many of us writing checks just after January 1, was a year off in dating this photo. Nicholas Emil Herman Adolph Ahlers, according to The Democratic banner., December 29, 1914, Image 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88078751/1914-12-29/ed-... which uses this photo. Ahlers was a naturalized Englishman who was tried for high treason. The charge was that he kept Germany posted on military and diplomatic activities at the opening of WWI. From NYT of December 10, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F15FF3F5C13738... "Nicholas Ahlers, former German Consul in Sunderland, was today convicted by the Durham Assizes of high treason and sentenced to death. " But a few days later, on appeal, the sentence was annulled. Helping German citizens return home (which was actually consistent with a government order) was not necessarily hostile to British interests. And instructions to the jury seem to have been inadequate. See New-York tribune., December 19, 1914, Page 2 (column 6 towards bottom) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1914-12-19/ed-...
Thanks swanq, the first newspaper link with the identical photo is very helpful. We'll fix the spelling of his name.

See some ephemera for sale at www.heldfond.com/pages/books/8719/hoboes-of-america-jeff-... He introduced the idea of the Hotel de Gink, a shelter managed by the homeless for themselves. Here's a NY Times article referring to Martin Saxe as "Republican nominee for State Senator in the Seventeenth District".

This is probably taken from around the time of his appointment by Gov. Whitman as President of the New York State Tax Commission: Biographical sketch from New York Red Book, 1917: MARTIN SAXE The Hon. Martin Saxe President of the State Tax Commission was born in New York City August 28 1874 and is the son of Fabian and Theresa Helburn Saxe. He received his education in Public School No 69 Dwight School Princeton University and New York Law School. He was admitted to the bar in 1897. In 1902 Mr Saxe was appointed Assistant Corporation Counsel in charge of the Bureau for the Collection of Arrears of Personal Taxes of the Law Department of the City of New York. In 1904 he was elected to the State Senate from the Seventeenth Senate District and in 1906 he was re elected from the Eighteenth Senate District. During his four years service in the Senate Mr. Saxe was a member of the Committee on Taxation and was also a member of the Special Tax Commission of 1906. Mr. Saxe was elected to the Constitutional Convention of 1915 from the Eighteenth Senate District and was appointed Chairman of the Committee on Taxation of that body by President Elihu Root. In the early part of that year he assisted in the preparation of the bill for the establishment of the State Tax Department and after the passage of that law was appointed President of the State Tax Commission by Governor Whitman. Mr Saxe is a co author of Powell's Taxation of Corporations He introduced the net earnings rule in this State now widely used in the valuation of special franchises for purposes of taxation. This rule was first applied by Commissioner Saxe sitting as referee in certiorari proceedings to review the special franchises of the Brooklyn Queens County and Suburban Railroad and the Brooklyn City Railroad, and followed by the referee in the Jamaica Water Supply case, now the leading case on this subject. Opinion reported in New York Law Journal March 5 1907. He is a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the New York County Lawyers Association, the International Law Society, the National Tax Association and the Lotos, Princeton, Lawyers', Republican and Columbia Yacht Clubs. books.google.com/books?id=l3FIAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA94&o...

Scandal from Detroit: Arthur Little, a druggist, sought to divorce his wife Alma in 1914-15, because she "concealed Negro blood in her veins." Mrs. Little was a pale blonde, and denied that she had any African ancestry. She came to New York to visit the anthropologist Franz Boas, who pronounced that "If this golden-haired blond really has Negro blood in her veins, not a husband in the world can feel assured that his wife is not a Negress." The couple divorced on grounds of cruelty instead. This story turns up in Elizabeth M. Smith-Pryor, Property Rites: The Rhinelander Trial, Passing, and the Protection of Whiteness (UNC Press 2009): 166.

From the Batavia NY Daily News, 19 December 1914, p. 4:
HER RACE UNKNOWN. Woman Declared a Negress Will Ask Aid of Scientists Ann Arbor, Mich., Dec. 19.--In an effort to obtain scientific evidence in support of her contention that she has no negro blood in her veins, as charged by her husband, who seeks a divorce. Mrs. Alma Little of Detroid consulted several medical experts connected with the University of Michigan. Every test showed the woman to be white, yet such authorities as Dr. Victor Vaughn, president of the American Medical Association, admitted he dare not make an affidavit to such a statement, saying that no method has been discovered by which it is possible to definitely to determine by scientific methods if a person had negro blood. Mrs. Little is arranging a journey to Eastern cities and to seek the aid of such scientists as George Grant, Franz Boas, and Alex Herdlcka in determining her race.
A similar newspaper account: news.google.com/newspapers?id=1ostAAAAIBAJ&sjid=85wFA...

DNSF: Higher resolution images are available at the Library of Congress website. Follow the link towards the bottom of the description ... hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3b48759. The more complicated part of the story: the Library has been digitizing collections since the early 1990s. As stronger imaging capabilities become available, we adopt them. But with 1.25 million digitized items today, we don't get to go back too often and re-scan pictures. As a result, you'll find a wide variety of image resolutions representing the LOC collections in Flickr. For this WPA poster, the TIFF file on our website is 4.3 MB, which is typical for much of this collection with is 900 posters scanned in the 1990s and 2000. The TIFF for the elephant poster (which was recently re-scanned for a special project) weighs in at 38MB, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3k00002. It's hard to keep it all straight, so we do document the scanning specification that covers the bulk of a collection. The WPA poster settings are described at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/wpapos/digitizing.html --Helena (LOC)

The Sioux City Community Federal Art Center was one of 50 such centers established as part of the WPA Federal Art Project, in the words of its director to "bring art back into the healthy channels of everyday life. We are trying to make art mean something to the 120 million American people, and particularly to those of the 120 million who, in the past, have not had the opportunity to enjoy art. Anybody can appreciate art. The extent of this appreciation of art depends upon opportunity and experience. In a democracy such as ours, art can and ought to belong to everybody. We are trying our best to bring it to all." newdeal.feri.org/ala/al38807.htm (Bulletin of the Amercan Library Ass'n., Oct. 15, 1938). The Sioux City Art Center got its first acquisitions and first permanent art space where this exhibition was held, in the basement of the August Williges building, a Prarie School structure which is now a landmark. The basement was renovated by 150 local volunteers into classrooms and galleries. The Art Center opened on February 20, 1938, which helps date this poster. It remained in the Williges building until 1954. webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:i8uBMezzpVI... When the federal program ended in 1940, the city took over the organization and it became, and remains, the Sioux City Art Center. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sioux_City_Art_Center

bobjenz: Do a Google search on "Keep your teeth clean" and you will see lots of copies of the image, some from vendors who will be happy to sell you a poster made from LoC's digital images. Or you can follow the Persistent URL link and download the highest-resolution image and print it out yourself. These posters were scanned in the 1990s (see note from Helena (LOC) at www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6629872501/ ) and the resolution is fairly low. So don't expect to be able to blow it up very big -- and don't expect the vendors to be able to do that either, even if their website says they can sell you a large poster.

Gustav Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Krupp_von_Bohlen_und_Halbach Gustav Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach was born Gustav von Bohlen und Halbach. He married Bertha Krupp in October 1906. He lead Krupp heavy industries until early WWII, Read the Arms of Krupp for an extensive history of the family and company. Two interesting things about his name. Firstly, Krupp, although more important in the economic sense, is first, because the highest title name generally goes last, in this case the noble "von". Second, the Kaiser announced at the wedding he would be allowed to add the Krupp name to his own, indicating the prominence the Krupp name had achieved already.

Alfred von Tirpitz (March 19, 1849 – March 6, 1930) was a German Admiral, Secretary of State of the German Imperial Naval Office, the powerful administrative branch of the German Imperial Navy from 1897 until 1916. Prussia never had a major navy, nor did the other German states before the German Empire was formed in 1871. Tirpitz took the modest imperial navy and starting in the 1890s turned it into a world-class force that could threaten the British Royal Navy. His navy however was not strong enough to confront the British successfully in World War I; the one great naval Battle of Jutland was a draw. Tirpitz turned to submarine warfare, which antagonized the United States. He was dismissed in 1916 and never regained power. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_von_Tirpitz

With his great forked beard, and instantly recognizable man in his time.  The "Father of the German Navy". It was his insistence that a ship's first duty was to not sink, making the German heavy ships able to withstand severe punishment they absorbed on multiple occasions.

Qingdao (help·info) (Chinese: 青岛; pinyin: Qīngdǎo; Mandarin pronunciation: [tɕʰíŋtɑ̀ʊ̯]; German: Tsingtau) also known in the West by its postal map spelling Tsingtao, is a major city with a population of over 8.715 million (2010 census) in eastern Shandong province, Eastern China. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qingdao Identified by the German authorities as a strategically important port, Qingdao was administered by the Imperial Department of the Navy (Reichsmarineamt) rather than the Imperial Colonial Office (Reichskolonialamt). The navy based their Far East Squadron there, allowing the ships to conduct operations throughout the Pacific. Beginning January 1898 the marines of III. Seebatallion were based at Tsingtao. Before the outbreak of World War I the ships of the German naval forces under Admiral Count von Spee were located at central Pacific colonies on routine missions. The fleet then rendezvoused in the Marianas to plan a transit to Germany rather than be trapped in the Pacific by Allied fleets. After a minor British naval attack on the German colony in 1914, Japan occupied the city and the surrounding province during the Siege of Tsingtao after Japan's declaration of war on Germany in accordance with the Anglo-Japanese Alliance. The failure of the Allied powers to restore Chinese rule to Shandong after the war triggered the May Fourth Movement.

Lucy Kyle Burleson (1894-1967), a yeowoman in the Navy, and a daughter of Postmaster General Albert S. Burleson (1856-1937) and Mrs. Adele Lubbock Steiner Burleson (1856-1948), was married to Ensign Charles Greene Grimes, II (1893-1993), U.S.N.R., on November 2, 1918, in Washington, D.C.  Ensign Grimes of Dayton, Ohio, was a son of Edward D. Grimes and Eleanor B. Leyler Grimes. [1] [2] [3] President and Mrs. Wilson, Vice President Marshall, the Secretary of State and Mrs. Lansing, Mrs. William Gibbs McAdoo (President Wilson’s daughter, Eleanor Randolph Wilson married to the Secretary of Treasury), as well as many other members of the Cabinet were among the invited guests. [4] Three years earlier, Lucy was at the center of much engagement speculation in Washington as she was frequently in the company of Justice James Clark McReynolds of the Supreme Court. Lucy was twenty-one at the time and McReynolds was fifty-three. [5] In 1914, Lucy Burleson was active in the "cotton week" sales and activities to stimulate the cotton industries and aid the South. [6] Charles rose to the rank of US Navy Captain, serving in the Pacific Fleet during World War II. He was appointed by President Franklin D Roosevelt to be the US Navy’s Assistant Secretary, and was an advisor to the President on chemicals. After the war, Charles was a chemist and general manager for a varnish company. Charles and Lucy lived at Van Buren, Montgomery County, Ohio, from late in 1919 and had three children – Adele Grimes Castle (1919-2008), Eleanor Grimes Butt (b.1921), and Burleson (Burley) Grimes (Sr.) (1922-1982).  When Lucy Kyle Burleson Grimes died in 1967 she had twelve grandchildren. [7] [8] [9] There is another photograph of Lucy, from the Bain Collection of The Library of Congress, here:   Note: A "Special to The" New York Times article of October 30, 1918, I believe, misidentifies the groom as "Ensign Edward Greene Grimes". Edward Grimes was the father of the groom, Charles Greene Grimes, II. All other (multiple) references identify the groom as Charles Green Grimes, the son of Edward Greene Grimes – as have I in this comment.

The group is almost, but not exactly the same in the Times.  "Miss Morgan" is identified as Camilla Morgan.

In July 1917, a Miss Camilla Morgan, who was a prominent suffragist in New York City, married Ensign James C. White of the Massachusetts Naval Reserve, at the home of his godmother, Mrs. T. F. Richardson, at Cohasset MA. (The wedding was secret, so it was only announced several weeks later, in a short note in the New York Times, 10 August 1917.) They had a daughter born in New York City within a couple years after they married. James (1895-1981) eventually became Chief of Neurosurgery at Massachusetts General Hospital: neurosurgery.mgh.harvard.edu/white/default.htm westnsurg.org/society/bio.aspx?MemberID=2879

"Catherine Porter" appears as Katherine Porter in the newspapers, another photo of her is in the New-York tribune., June 13, 1915, Page 6, Image 24 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-06-13/ed-... See also www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/27255131166/

The third Governor of Oklahoma, Robert Lee Williams, had just been elected in the Fall of 1914: "Robert Lee Williams, Democrat. Served from 1915 to 1919. Oklahoma's third Governor was born December 20, 1868, at Brundidge, Alabama. He earned an LL.D., was admitted to the Alabama Bar in 1891, and began his practice in Troy, Alabama. In 1896, he went to Atoka, Indian Territory. His years of public service included: Member of the Constitutional Convention, 1906 to 1907; Chief Justice of the Oklahoma Supreme Court, 1907 to 1914; Governor of Oklahoma, January 11, 1915 to January 13, 1919; United States District Judge, Eastern District of Oklahoma, 1919 to 1937; United States Circuit Judge, Tenth Circuit, 1937 to 1939. He died at his home in Durant, Oklahoma, April 10, 1948, and is buried in City Cemetery in Durant." www.odl.state.ok.us/oar/governors/williams.htm see also: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_L._Williams

"After seeing Charlotte Davies do her posing act at Hammerstein's theater -- an act that included "Statue of a Maiden", "September Morn", "The Bath", "The Dancer", and the suspect-sounding "The White Slave", -- Variety's "Jolo" dismissed the routine as "merely  a vulgar display of robust undraped femininity"  -- "Blue Vaudeville: Sex, Morals and the Mass Marketing of Amusement, 1895-1915" by Andrew L. Erdman, page 193.
Here's a Google Books source about Charlotte Davies, from The Green Book Magazine.

Another review:
"Charlotte Davies is still defying the changeable Spring weather at the Victoria.
Such confidence in a gold bracelet; deserves its reward.
Indeed, there is little about Miss Davies to commentupon. But it was sheer enthusiasm to call her poses living " pictures."
-Dramatic Mirror, May-June 1915.
See also for comments by Charlotte Davies' descendants about her life.

Another photo of Charlotte Davies:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6482044429/]

Rennold Wolf in The Green Book Magazine of July, 1914: AWFUL MOMENT AT HAMMERSTEIN'S EVEN the placid William Hammerstein almost gave way to an outburst of emotion at the Victoria Theatre one afternoon this spring when a harrowing incident, which might have fractured all three of the dramatic unities, took place. The headliner for the week, if you please, was none other than Charlotte Davies, who first gained fame by posing for the picture of "Innocence" which now adorns art store windows, and subsequently clinched her distinction by becoming a party in a divorce action. That combination was irresistible to Hammerstein, and, although Miss Davies had never before been on the stage, he engaged her at a large salary, and gave her prominence over a half-dozen seasoned and popular veterans on the bill. Miss Davies had no further contribution to offer art. apparently, than the curves which had gained her success in the pose of "Innocence." A platform, velvet curtains and a pink union suit were her other accoutrements. Thus equipped, Mr. Hammerstein bade her to sprawl twice a day upon the carpeted floor of the platform, in a series of misnamed poses under the guise of art, and to call at the manager's office Saturday night for her hire. There were unholy and unregenerate persons in the audience whose appreciation of art was not so keen as Mr. Hammerstein's, and they displayed a tendency to snicker at the ever broad ening revelations of the model, as she struck first one, and then another position best calculated to exhibit her charms. It was, therefore, in sight of an audience almost on the verge of an outbreak that Miss Davies, in one of her most generous poses, was horrorstricken by the appearance of a mouse that had wandered from his hidingplace to the platform, quite unmindful that he was menacing the cause of uplift. There was a moment of awful suspense, suffered most intensely by the model. It was her duty to be statuesque, but the quiver that ran over her frame showed its undulations even through the union suit. Her attitude—that of a Roman maiden gazing into a bath—was not one to make escape easy. The mouse crept nearer, and again the wavy motion of the union suit betrayed Miss Davies' emotion. He gathered himself together is if to spring; the statue began to wobble, when— Excelsior!—from the wings came Loney Haskell, the Victoria's general factotum and handy man, armed with a broom, and the rascally rodent fled. The velvet curtains were drawn amid thunders of applause. Art had triumphed again at Hammerstein's. books.google.com/books?id=qX8hAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA76#v=onep...

6/3/20  I was just forwarded this from my sister-in-law. What a surprise! Charlotte was my Grandmother! I knew she had an "artsy" background, but never heard of this incident. Wow...Thanks much for discovering this.
Ken Carter ( 76 yrs)  knecarter@aol.com  
Mtn View, Cal.

I also just learned of this information.  Miss Charlotte Davies was my great grandmother.  
I wish to include more information about my gr grandmother.  She was married very young and had one daughter, Jewell.  Charlotte's husband left her as a single mother in her late teenage years. I know of Charlotte's extreme devotion to her daughter (my grandmother).  My grandmother deeply loved her mother and was raised with honor and access to a wonderful life where she found love, marriage, a beautiful home and family with two sons, George Carter (my father) and Ken Carter  (my uncle).  I have learned of the struggles a single mother faced during those days and I understand Charlotte was a strong survivor and did all she could to provide a very safe/secure life for Jewell. Charlotte was very beautiful and like many women in our history.......this became an asset to acquire money through film and photography.  I understand these photos of Charlotte would be considered in poor taste (an understatement) during those times. However, Charlotte had great pride and integrity.  She was exceptionally smart and had tremendous charm and high personal integrity with class.  These photos should not be a reflection of the true personality of Charlotte, but a reflection of the times and the plight of single mothers/women.  I wish more people knew the true story of Charlotte.  This would be an opportunity to gain insight of those times in society and the fight many women endured.
Julie Carter-Williams

There is an obituary in the 11/10/12 New York Times for Francisco Estrada Cabrera, eldest son of the Guatemalan president, dead in Guatemala City at age 21. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B05E4D9133CE6... However, this may be an error. Other accounts say that Diego was his eldest son, Francisco the next of three sons. Diego had been schooled in Berkeley, California. One account has Diego fatally ill with "consumption" in 1910, racing home from Europe to die in Guatemala.
artolog:  Thanks for the additional information and the link--useful when we make our update.

I have found a more authoritative source, a biography of Manuel Estrada Cabrera. Francisco (Paco or Paquito) Estrada, aka Francisco Estrada Ocampo, committed suicide in the presidential palace on November 8, 1912. However, this picture is obviously much earler than 1913. He was the eldest (legitimate) son at the time of his death, as his older brother Diego had died in 1910, either of TB or as a suicide motivated by his illness. www.archive.org/details/eccepericles00arguat The memoir quoted by Swanq, above, tells the story of Francisco's death as related to the author by his father, called to the presidential palace that night.

Likely the wife and children of David Franklin Houston, "academic, businessman and politician."

David Franklin Houston married Texas-born Helen Beall (1873-1940) in 1895. Here's her tombstone in New York: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=66436070 They had five children all together, sons Duval, David Jr., and Lawrence, daughters Elizabeth and Helen. Helen Beall Houston wrote an unpublished memoir; her son David typed it up with some additional notes, and donated it to the Herman Brown Free Library in Burnet TX after her death.
bior and pennylrichardsca: Thanks for providing more information on Houston.  We'll include her full name next time we update.

The above comments are correct; thank you! Helen Beall (b. 1873) in Travis County (Austin) Texas She married David Franklin Houston (b. 1866 in Monroe, Union County, NC) on Dec. 11, 1895. Their first two children, DuVal Beall Houston and Helen Elizabeth Houston died young in Texas. David Franklin Jr. (b. 1898 in Austin, TX) died Feb. 1972 in New York, NY. The middle child above was my mother, Helen Beall Houston (Jr.) b. July 16, 1911 and who died in Los Angeles, CA, in 1996. The baby is Lawrence Reid Houston of Washington, DC, who died in 1998 (see CIA info online). All except Helen Beall Houston, my mother, are buried in Oyster Bay, Long Island, NY.
